Bond means any form of security including cash deposit, surety bond, collateral, property, or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the board of commissioners. All bonds shall be approved by the board of commissioners wherever a bond is required by this chapter. Buffer means a portion of a lot set aside for open space and visual screening between land uses to minimize conflicts between them. Buildable area means that portion of any lot which may be used or built upon in accordance with the regulations governing the given zoning district within which the particular lot is located, once the various front, side, and rear yard setbacks required for the land use have been subtracted from the total area. Building means any structure built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, or movable property of any kind, and includes any structure. Building area means the total area taken on a horizontal plane at the main grade level of the principal building and all accessory buildings, exclusive of uncovered porches, terraces and steps. Building height means the vertical distance from the established average sidewalk grade, street grade or finished grade at the building lines, whichever is the highest, to the highest point of the building. Building line means the inner edge of any required yard or required setback, and the corresponding outer edge of the buildable area. Except as specifically provided by this chapter, no portion of any building or structure may be extended to occupy any portion of a lot outside its building lines. Building, main, means a building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which it is situated. In any residential district, any dwelling shall be deemed to be a main building on the lot on which it is situated. Building official means the authorized building inspector for the county. Building permit means a written permit for construction issued by the office of planning and zoning. Building setback line means a line delineating the minimum allowable distance between the property line and a building on a lot within which no building or other structure shall be placed except as otherwise provided. Building setback, front, means the minimum allowable distance between the centerline of an abutting street, or an official future street, and the front of a building or structure on a lot. The front setback distance is applied to the full width of the lot and is parallel to or concentric with the street centerline. Building setback, rear, means the minimum allowable distance between the rear property line and a building or structure on a lot. The rear setback applies to and extends across the full width of the lot. Building setback, side, means the minimum allowable distance between the side property line and a building or structure on a lot. The side setback applies to the full depth of a lot. Building site means the ground area of a building together with all open spaces surrounded by the building. Care home means a rest home, nursing home, convalescent home, home for the aged or similar use established and operated to provide lodging and meals and/or domiciliary care for aged, infirm, chronically ill or convalescent persons. Centerline means the line determined as such by the official authority having jurisdiction over the street, otherwise it shall be the succession of midpoints between the identifiable limits of any improvements on the ground or of any easement. Child care center, commercial, means any place operated by any person or group wherein are received for pay not more than 18 children under 18 years of age for care and supervision less than 24 hours per day. Child care center, family, means a private residence operated by any person who receives therein for pay for supervision and care fewer than 24 hours a day, without transfer of legal custody, three but not more than six children under 18 years of age who are not related to such persons and whose parents or guardians are not residents in the same private residence. Clinic means an establishment where medical or dental patients, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination or treatment. Club, lodge, civic or fraternal organization means buildings and facilities owned or operated by a corporation, association, or person for a social, educational, religious, or recreational purpose but not primarily for profit or to render a service which is customarily carried on as a business. Communications tower means a tower of any size located on a nonresidential site, which supports communication equipment (transmission or receiving) utilized by commercial, government, or other public and quasi-public users. This does not include private home use or satellite dish and television antennas or amateur radio operators as licensed by the Federal Communications Commission, and excluding those used exclusively for dispatch communications. Condominium means individual ownership of units combined with a joint ownership of common areas and/or facilities of the building and grounds. Construction plan means the maps and/or drawings accompanying a subdivision plat or plan which shows the specific location and design of improvements to be installed in the subdivision in accordance with the requirements of the planning commission as a condition of the approval of the plat or plan. Convenience establishment: (1) Convenience store means a one-story, retail store containing less than 2,000 square feet of gross floor area that is designed and stocked to sell primarily food, beverages, household supplies and other convenience goods on a small-scale basis. (2) Convenience gas station means buildings and premises where gasoline and oil may be dispensed at retail. Uses permissible also include the sale of cold drinks, package foods, tobacco and similar convenience goods for station customers. Customary home occupation means a business, profession, occupation, or trade conducted for gain or support by any occupant of a dwelling and located entirely within a residential building, or a structure accessory thereto, which use is accessory, incidental, and secondary to the use of the building for dwelling purposes and does not change the essential residential character or appearance of such building. Dedication means the transfer of private property to public ownership and for public use upon written acceptance by the county. Developer means the owner or his representative of a lot or of any land included in a proposed development. Also, the holder of an option or contract to purchase, or any other person having enforceable proprietary interest in such land. Director or building official includes the word "designee." Director of planning and zoning or director is the person named to assist the planning commission in performing its duties. Driveway means a private roadway providing access for vehicles to one parking space, garage, dwelling or other structure. Dwelling means any building or portion thereof, which is designed or used exclusively for residential purposes. Dwelling, multifamily, means a building designed for and used as a residence for three or more families, and consisting of three or more separate dwelling units. Dwelling, single-family, means a structure, including a site-built, modular or manufactured home (a mobile home is not a single-family dwelling), that contains one dwelling unit designed for residential use exclusively by one family that is surrounded by open space on the same lot. All single-family dwellings shall meet the appearance standards as provided in section 34-522. Dwelling, two-family, means a building containing not more than two housekeeping units, and designed or used to house not more than two families, living independently of each other. Dwelling unit means a structure or a portion of any structure designed, arranged and used for living quarters for one or more persons living as a single housekeeping unit with cooking facilities, but not including units in hotels, motels, boardinghouses or like uses. Easement means a grant by a property owner to the use of land by the public, a corporation, or persons for specific purposes, including but not limited to the construction of utilities, access and drainageways. Easement, access means an access easement shall serve no more than four lots. The minimum lot size for a lot served solely by an access easement is five acres. An access easement must be a minimum of 50 feet, 30 feet for right-of-way and ten feet on each side for utilities, which shall NOT be included when calculating the road frontage of the parcel providing the access easement. Each parcel served by the access easement shall meet minimum road frontage requirements on the easement. Engineer means a registered, practicing engineer, licensed by the state, hired by the county to carry out the applicable provisions of this chapter. Escrow means a deposit of cash with the governing authority or escrow agent to secure the promise to perform some act. Establishment means any business regulated by this chapter. Family means one or more persons occupying a single dwelling unit provided that unless all members are related by blood, legal adoption or marriage, shall contain no more than five persons. Further provided that domestic servants employed on the premises may be housed on the premises. Family, immediate, means one or more persons, or parents, with their direct lineal descendants and legally cared-for or adopted children, living together in the whole or part of a dwelling, comprising a single housekeeping unit. Flag means a cloth with colors, patterns, etc. used as a signal. Frontage means that side of a lot abutting on a street or way ordinarily regarded as the front of the lot. Governing authority means the chair and board of commissioners of the county. Grade means the slope of a road, street, or other public way, specific in percentage terms from the horizontal. Gross floor area (GFA) means the total area of a building measured by taking the outside dimensions of the building at each floor level intended for occupancy or storage. Health department means the health department duly authorized to perform health services in the county. Horizontal curve means a winding, nonstraight section of road where the grade does not necessarily change. Individual sewage disposal system means a septic tank, seepage tile sewage disposal system or any other sewage treatment device. Industrialized housing means a factory fabricated transportable building consisting of units designed for incorporation into a permanent structure at a building site on a permanent foundation to be used for residential purposes; also known as a modular home. A modular home shall be certified by the manufacturer to meet the approval of the state commissioner of community affairs and to meet the same requirements as a site-built home within the county. An industrialized housing unit is a single-family dwelling and its placement in a residential district must meet or exceed the appearance standards as provided in section 34-522. Junkyard or salvage yard means any lot, land or structure or part thereof, used primarily for the collecting, storage or sale of waste paper, rags, scrap metal or other discarded material; and for the collecting, dismantling, storage, or salvage of machinery or vehicles not in running condition, or for the sale of parts thereof. Kennel means any place where dogs, cats, or other animals over three months of age are kept, raised, sold, boarded, bred, shown, treated or groomed. Landscape architect means a registered, practicing landscape architect licensed by the state. Lot means a parcel of land and includes the word "plot," "land" or "parcel." Lot, corner, means a lot located at the intersection of two or more streets. Lot, double frontage, means a lot having frontage on two streets as distinguished from a corner lot. Lot, flag, means a tract or lot of land of uneven dimensions in which the portion fronting on a street is less than the minimum width required for construction of a building or structure on that lot. No flag lots shall be created within the unincorporated area of the county. Lot, interior, means a lot other than a corner lot. Lot, nonconforming, means a lot legally existing at the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived (and not created for the purposes of evading the restrictions of this chapter) that does not meet the minimum area requirements of the district in which the lot is located.
Lot area means the total horizontal ground area inside lot lines, exclusive of any area open to the public. Lot coverage means the computed ground area occupied by buildings and other impervious surfaces, including but not limited to parked structures, driveways, roads, sidewalks, and areas covered with concrete asphalt, within a lot. Lot depth means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines measured in the general direction of the side lines of the lot. Lot frontage means the distance for which the front property line and street line coincide. Lot improvement means any building, structure, place, work of art, or other object, or improvement of the land on which they are situated constituting a physical betterment of real property, or any part of such betterment. Lot of record means a lot or parcel of land whose existence, location, and dimensions have been recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county. Lot width means the horizontal distance across the lot measured at right angles to the depth of the lot at the center of the minimum front yard setback lines. Manufactured home, class A, means a dwelling unit fabricated in an off-site facility for installation or assembly at the building site, bearing a label certifying that it is constructed in compliance with the Federal Manufactured Home and Standards Act 42, USC 5401—5445 (i.e., Constructed to the HUD Code which became effective on June 15, 1976), and meeting the following development standards: (1) The home has a minimum width in excess of 16 feet. (2) The pitch of the home's roof has a minimum vertical rise of three feet for each 12 feet of horizontal run, and the roof is finished with a type of shingle that is commonly used in conventional residential construction. (3) The exterior siding consists of wood, hardboard, vinyl, brick, masonry, or aluminum (vinyl-covered or painted, but in no case exceeding the reflectivity of gloss white paint) comparable in composition, appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used in conventional residential construction. (4) A masonry, mortar joint curtain wall (skirting), unpierced except for required ventilation and access, installed so that it encloses the area located under the home to the ground level. The wall must have a minimum thickness of four inches, and must be constructed of commonly used standard clay brick or standard concrete block. (5) The tongue, axles, transporting lights, and towing apparatus are removed after placement on the lot and before occupancy. (6) Landings shall be installed prior to occupancy of the requisite composition and size pursuant to the Code being enforced by state law, with provisions being expressly incorporated by reference therein as part of this requirement. (7) The manufactured home must be installed in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-130 et seq. and 8-2-160 et seq., to include poured concrete footers. (8) A class A manufactured home, if constructed outside the boundaries of the county may be brought into the county and used as a dwelling if such home was constructed ten years or less from the date of permit application. (9) Manufactured homes may not be used for any other purpose or use other than the residential use originally designed and approved by HUD. Manufactured home, class B, means a dwelling unit fabricated in an off-site facility for installation or assembly at the building site, bearing a label certifying that it is constructed in compliance with the Federal Manufactured Home and Standards Act 42, USC 5401—5445 (i.e., constructed to the HUD Code which became effective on June 15, 1976), and meeting the following development standards: (1) The pitch of the home's roof has a minimum vertical rise of three feet for each 12 feet of horizontal run, and the roof is finished with a type of shingle that is commonly used in conventional residential construction. (2) The exterior siding consists of wood, hardboard, vinyl, brick, masonry, or aluminum (vinyl-covered or painted, but in no case exceeding the reflectivity of gloss white paint) comparable in composition, appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used in conventional residential construction. (3) A masonry, mortar joint curtain wall (skirting), unpierced except for required ventilation and access, installed so that it encloses the area located under the home to the ground level. The wall must have a minimum thickness of four inches, and must be constructed of commonly used standard clay brick or standard concrete block. (4) The tongue, axles, transporting lights and towing apparatus are removed after placement on the lot and before occupancy. (5) Landings shall be installed prior to occupancy of the requisite composition and size pursuant to the Code being enforced by state law, with provisions being expressly incorporated by reference therein as part of this requirement. (6) The manufactured home must be installed in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-130 et seq. and 8-2-160 et seq., to include poured concrete footers. (7) A class B manufactured home, if constructed outside the boundaries of the county may be brought into the county and used as a dwelling if such home was constructed ten years or less from the date of permit application. (8) Manufactured homes may not be used for any other purpose or use other than the residential use originally designed and approved by HUD. Manufactured home, class C, means a dwelling unit fabricated in an off-site facility for installation or assembly at the building site, bearing a label certifying it is constructed in compliance with the Federal Manufactured Home and Standards Act 42, USC 5401—5445 (i.e., constructed to the HUD Code which became effective on June 15, 1976), but does not satisfy the criteria necessary to qualify the unit as a class A or B manufactured home and meeting the following development standards: (1) The exterior siding consists of wood, hardboard, vinyl, brick, masonry, or aluminum (vinyl-covered or painted, but in no case exceeding the reflectivity of gloss white paint) comparable in composition, appearance, and durability to the exterior siding commonly used in conventional residential construction. (2) A vinyl curtain wall (skirting), unpierced except for required ventilation and access, installed so that it encloses the area located under the home to the ground level. (3) Landings shall be installed prior to occupancy, and of the requisite composition and size pursuant to the building code being enforced by state law, with the provisions being expressly incorporated by reference therein as part of this requirement. (4) The manufactured home must be installed in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-130 et seq. and 8-2-160 et seq. Poured concrete footers may not be required. (5) The tongue, axles, transporting lights, and towing apparatus are removed after placement on the lot and before occupancy. (6) Manufactured homes may not be used for any other purpose or use other than the residential use originally designed and approved by HUD. (7) A class C manufactured home, if constructed outside the boundaries of the county may be brought into the county and used as a dwelling if such home was constructed ten years or less from the date of permit application. A class C manufactured home may be relocated within the county provided the home was constructed ten years or less from the date of permit application. A class C manufactured home constructed to the HUD Code which became effective on June 15, 1976, more than ten years from the date of permit application, may be located only within an approved manufactured home park. Manufactured home park means any property on which ten or more manufactured homes are located or intended to be located for purposes of residential or recreational occupancy of a temporary, seasonal, or permanent nature. Manufactured home parks must comply with the specific requirements for such parks as delineated in sections 34-591—34-597. Manufactured home space means a unit of ground, as prescribed by sections 34-591—34-597, which shall be clearly indicated by corner markers, on which may be placed a manufactured home. Modular home: See industrialized housing. Must is mandatory. Neighborhood shopping centers consist entirely or primarily of convenient goods outlets with a supermarket as anchoring tenant. Neighborhood shopping centers generally do not have enclosed air conditioned malls, elaborate landscaping or similar amenities typical of larger shopping centers. Nonconforming use means any building, structure or use of land existing at the time of enactment of this chapter which does not comply with or conform to the provisions of the zoning district in which it is located. Nursing home means any dwelling in which aged, chronically ill or incurable persons are housed and furnished with meals and nursing care for compensation. Official zoning map means the map approved by the planning commission and adopted by the county which identifies each zoning district in the county. Off-site means any premises not located within the area of the property to be subdivided whether or not in the same ownership of the applicant for subdivision approval. Off-street loading space means the area required to load or unload goods or other materials plus the necessary driveways and maneuvering areas. Off-street parking space means the area required to park one automobile plus the necessary driveways and maneuvering areas. Open space means a parcel of land or an area of water or a combination of both land and water within the designated development, designed and intended for the use and enjoyment of residents of the development or for the general public, not including streets or off-street parking areas. Open space shall be substantially free of structures, but may contain such improvements as are in the plans as finally approved and are appropriate for the benefit of residents of the development. Owner means any individual, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, corporation, trust, or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under the regulations. Parcel means a general term including all plots of land shown with separate identification on the official tax appraisal maps. Parcels may or may not be buildable lots, depending upon whether or not such parcels are created in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter. Parking space. See off-street parking space. Paved-way width means the shortest distance as measured from curb face to curb face or, if without curbing, as measured from edge of pavement to edge of pavement. Personal care home/assisted living means a building occupied as a permanent primary residence and also occupied by up to six unrelated ambulatory adults who reside there temporarily or longterm and receive services, including room, meals and personal care from the permanent occupants. Planned unit development (PUD) or planned development district (PDD) means any planned concentration which provides for innovative concepts in large-scale residential, commercial, or industrial development which enables economy in capital expenditures or utilities and streets and in subsequent maintenance. Plat means the schematic representation of land. Plat, final, means the plat submitted to the planning commission for final approval and, subsequently, to be recorded with the clerk of superior court of the county. Plat, preliminary, means the plat or layout of a proposed subdivision submitted to the planning commission for approval prior to submission of the final plat. Principal building means a building in which the principal use of the lot or tract of land is conducted. Principal use means the primary use of land or structures as distinguished from a special use or accessory use. Public improvement means any drainage ditch, roadway, parkway, sidewalk, pedestrian way, tree, lawn, off-street parking area, lot improvement, or other facility for which the county may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which may affect an improvement for which the county responsibility is established. Public road means any road that has a dedicated right-of-way and services the general public, but is not owned or regularly maintained by the county. Public sewerage means a sanitary sewerage system for the collection of water borne wastes complete with a sewage treatment plant or stabilization pond. The entire system must be either operated by the county or have been approved by the county, in the case of a privatelyowned system. Public utilities means water, gas, sanitary and storm sewer, electrical, and communication lines and facilities, and natural or improved drainage facilities. Recreational vehicle. See travel trailer. Right-of-way line means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, road, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, storm or sanitary sewer main, shade trees, or for another special use and owned by the county. Rooming and/or boarding house means a residential structure which provides lodging with or without meals, is available for permanent occupancy only and which makes no provision for cooking in any of the rooms occupied by paying guests. Screening means either: (1) A strip at least ten feet wide, densely planted (or having equivalent natural growth) with shrubs or trees at least four feet high at the time of planting, of a type that will form a yearround dense screen at least six feet high; or (2) An opaque wall or barrier or uniformly painted fence at least six feet high. Service lane means a vehicular passageway providing secondary and/or service access to the sides or rear of building lots. Should is permissive. Shoulder means that portion of a street or road from the outer edge of the paved surface or the curb to the inside edge of the ditch, gutter or original ground surface. Sidewalk means that portion of a street or road available exclusively for pedestrian traffic. Sketch plat or site plan means a sketch plan or plat which is a generalized map prepared by the developer that shows the development concept. Its purpose is to serve as a basis for discussion before the subdivision process begins without either the director or the developer making commitments. Special use means a use permitted upon approval by the board of commissioners; a review and recommendation by the planning commission to this chapter covering conditions precedent or subsequent that are not precise enough to all applications without interpretation and such review and exception is provided for by this chapter. A special use permit is not a variance. Rather, it is a land use that can be made compatible with a principal use under certain standards and conditions. Street means a right-of-way for vehicular traffic whether designated a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, drive, expressway, freeway, boulevard, lane, place, circle, alley, or otherwise. Various types of streets may be defined as follows: Arterial means a public way which is used primarily for fast and heavy traffic flow; is of considerable continuity; and is used as a traffic artery for intercommunication among large areas. Collector means principal entrance streets to subdivisions and the main streets for circulation within the county which serve a network of four or more local streets. Collector streets are designed as a link between local streets and arterial streets. County means a street which is owned or maintained by the county. Cul-de-sac means a local street with only one outlet, closed and terminated by a vehicular turnaround. It shall not extend more than 1,200 feet in length and shall be provided with a turnaround having a minimum roadway diameter of at least 80 feet, a maximum roadway diameter of 200 feet, and a right-of-way diameter of at least 100 feet. Local means a street used primarily in residential subdivisions for access to abutting properties as opposed to the collection and dispersion of traffic. Marginal access means a street which is parallel to or adjacent to an arterial street or highway and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. Private means any road or street that is not publicly owned and maintained and used for access by the occupants of the development, their guests, and the general public. Private streets must be constructed to county standards. Street grade means the elevation of a paved street measured at the street centerline or curb. Street width means the shortest distance between the lines delineating the right-of-way of a street. Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a location on the ground, or attached to something having a location on the ground. Among other things, structure includes buildings, mobile homes, walls, fences, billboards and advertising signs. Subdivider means any individual, firm, association, syndicate, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity commencing or required by law to commence proceedings under these regulations to effect a subdivision of land hereunder for himself or for another. Subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots. Division of land means a subdivision of four or fewer lots, which does not involve the construction of a new public or private street, the construction of a community water system, or a community sewer system. These applications are processed administratively by the director of planning and zoning as final plat applications that do not require preliminary plat approval. Any improvements to an existing public street abutting the tract proposed for division of land, or the installation of utilities along said existing public road, as may be required to comply with this chapter, shall be done according to plans and permit requirements of this chapter, but said requirements shall not subject the division of land to the requirements for a major subdivision as specified in the chapter. Major subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of land into five or more lots which may or may not involve the construction of a new public street; or any subdivision that involves the construction of a new public or private street. If the major subdivision involves construction of a new public or private street or the upgrade of an existing private access way to county standards, construction plans and land disturbance permits are required. Major subdivisions are therefore processed in multiple steps including preliminary plat approval (unless specifically exempted), approval of construction plans and issuance of land disturbance permits, and final plat approval. Subdivision improvement agreement means a contract entered into by the applicant and the planning commission on behalf of the county by which the applicant promises to complete the required public improvements within the subdivision within a specified time period following final subdivision plat approval. Subdivision, residential means unified residential development that is developed as a whole in a single development operation or a definitely programmed series of development operations or phases. The essential features are a definable boundary; a consistent, but not necessarily uniform, character, overall control during the development process by a single development entity, construction of new roads; and enforcement of covenants, conditions, and restrictions by a master community association. Surveyor means a registered, practicing surveyor, licensed by the state or elected by the county. Tract means a lot. The term tract is used interchangeably with the term lot, particularly in the context of subdivisions, where one "tract" is subdivided into several "lots." Travel trailer/recreation vehicle means a motorized camper, tent trailer, or other similar vehicular or portable structure used or designed for temporary housing or occupancy while on vacation, recreational or other trip and provided with sleeping accommodations. Travel trailer park means any plot or tract of land on which two or more travel trailers are located. Use means the purpose for which land or a building or other structure is designed, arranged or intended or for which it is or may be occupied or maintained. Used or occupied, as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the terms intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied. Variance means a departure from any provision of the zoning requirements, except use, without changing the zoning ordinance or the underlying zoning of the parcel. A variance shall be granted only upon demonstration of a hardship based on the peculiarity of the property in relation to other properties in the same zoning district, as specified in this chapter. Vertical curve means a vertical curve is a hilly, nonflat section of road where the grade changes at some constant rate as a function of distance traveled. _____ Yard means a space on the same lot with a main building, such space being open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings or structures from the ground upwards, except where encroachments and accessory buildings are explicitly permitted. Yard _____ Yard, front, means an open, unoccupied space on same lot with the main building, extending the full width of the lot and situated between the right-of-way line and the front line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. Covered porches, whether enclosed or unenclosed, shall not project into a required front yard. On corner lots, the front yard shall be the open area between the main entrance of the structure and the street. Yard, rear, means an open space on the same lot with the main building, such space being unoccupied except possibly by an accessory building, and extending the full width of the lot and situated between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the main building projected to the side lines of the lot. On all corner lots, the rear yard shall be at the opposite end of the lot from the front yard. Yard, side, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building or use, located between the building or use and the side line of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. Zoning means the provisions of this chapter that regulate the manner, type, size and use to which a piece of property may be put. (Ord. No. 48, § 2-2, 1-9-2003; Ord. Sec. 34-31. - Planning commission. There shall be a planning commission consisting of five members. (1) Appointment and terms. a. Planning commission members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. For the purpose of appointing members to the planning commission, the county shall be divided into four districts which shall be coterminous with board of commissioners districts, one member of the planning commission shall be a resident of each such district. The fifth member shall be appointed by the chair from the county at large. Members shall serve four-year staggered terms and may continue until their successors are duly appointed. The board of commissioners shall have the right to remove any member of the planning commission for cause. b. The planning commission shall annually elect one of its members as chair. (2) Powers and duties. a. Specific limitations of powers. The planning commission does not have the power to amend these regulations, to rezone any land, to declare this chapter or any amendment thereto invalid or to allow any use not permitted by this chapter. b. Duties. The duties of the planning commission shall include: 1. Review and approve all plats. 2. Review and approve all development plans. 3. Review and approve all subdivision developmental plans. 4. Recommend to the board of commissioners approval or disapproval of all requests for zoning changes after a public hearing. 5. Recommend to the board of commissioners any changes in this chapter that the planning commission believes are appropriate. 6. Grant approval or denial of a special use permit after a public hearing. 7. Hear and make recommendations to the board of commissioners for approval or disapproval of all variances from the terms of this chapter after a public hearing. 8. Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that there is an error in any order, requirement, permit, decision or refusal made by the director or other administrative official in the administration or enforcement of any provisions of this chapter. 9. Questions involving interpretation of the zoning map ("official map"), including district boundary lines and lot lines, as provided in section 34-492. 10. Advise the board of commissioners on matters of zoning and land development as it may deem appropriate. 11. Conduct such other business and affairs as may be, from time to time, designated by the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 48, § 3-1, 1-9-2003) Cross reference— Other boards and commissions, § 2-141 et seq. Sec. 34-32. - Board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall hear and make decisions concerning: (1) Proposed amendments to this chapter; (2) Adoption and amendments to the zoning map and the text of the ordinance; (3) Applications for variances, as specified in section 34-383; and (4) Approval, disapproval or other action on all requests for zoning changes as provided in this chapter. (Ord. No. 48, § 3-2, 1-9-2003) Cross reference— Board of commissioners, § 2-31 et seq. Sec. 34-33. - Director of planning and zoning. The director of planning and zoning or director shall have the power and duty to provide the following services related to this chapter: (1) Issue and when necessary revoke building permits as specified in section 34-423. (2) Issue a certificate of occupancy as required in section 34-424. (3) Issue and when necessary revoke a manufactured home permit as specified in section 34-554. (4) Issue a sign permit. (5) Answer all questions of interpretation of the provisions of this chapter. (6) Administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (7) Meet with a developer, if requested, during a preapplication conference to discuss a development proposal as defined in section 34-102. (8) Dispense general information about this chapter to the public upon request. (9) Review and approve plats of existing parcels and divisions not to include major subdivisions. (10) Approve home occupations or cottage industries as uses permitted by right. (11) Approve minor variances in zoning dimensional requirements providing the intent of the dimensional requirements is maintained. (12) Approve minor variances of no more than 50 feet for prohibited uses within a designated entrance corridor. (Ord. No. 48, § 3-3, 1-9-2003; Ord. of 2-8-2018) Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-201 et seq. Secs. 34-34—34-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS
Sec. 34-61. - Generally. (a) Application of zoning provisions. Except as otherwise provided, no structure or land shall, after the adoption of this chapter, be used and no structure or part thereof shall be erected, altered or moved unless in conformity with the requirements specified in this chapter for the district in which it is located. (b) Application of subdivision provisions. No land shall be subdivided or sold, leased, transferred or developed until each of the following conditions has occurred in accordance with this chapter: (1) The developer or his agent has submitted the required fees, plats and plans as described in these regulations to the director; (2) Obtained approval of all these plats and plans, including approval of the final plat or plan by the planning commission or planning director; and (3) The approved final plat is recorded with the county clerk of superior court. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be considered minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity and general welfare of the community. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-1, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-62. - Area and setback requirements. Except as provided in this chapter, no building or structure shall be erected on a lot unless such building or structure, enlargement, additions or alterations conform with the area regulations and setback requirements of the zoning district in which it is located. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-2, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-63. - Reduction of lot area. No lot shall be reduced, diminished and so maintained that the yards, other open space or total lot area shall be smaller than prescribed by this chapter, nor shall the density of population be increased in any manner except in conformity with the regulations established in this chapter. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-3, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-64. - Yards apply to only one building. No required yard or other open space around an existing building, or which is hereafter provided around any building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter, shall be considered as providing a yard or open space for any other building; nor shall any yard or other required open space on an adjoining lot be considered as providing a yard or open space on a lot whereon a building is to be erected. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-4, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-65. - Only one main building on a lot. Every building hereafter shall be located on a lot. There shall not be more than one main residential building and its accessory buildings on one lot, except as otherwise provided. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-5, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-66. - Corner visibility. No sign, construction, structures, fence, wall, hedge, bushes, outdoor uses or other obstruction to a clear view which extends over three feet in height shall be permitted at any corner of intersecting streets and a straight line connecting them at points 25 feet from the intersection of the street lines. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-6, 1-9-2003) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62. Sec. 34-67. - Front yards on a double frontage lot. At each end of a double frontage lot there shall be a front yard of the depth required by this chapter for the zoning district in which each street frontage is located; provided, that one of the front yards may serve as a rear yard. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-7, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-68. - Suitability of land for subdivision. All land physically unsuitable for subdivision shall not be improved. This includes: (1) Damaged property. Property affected by flooding, bad drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, or other such features which may endanger health, life or property, aggravate erosion, increase flood hazard, or necessitate excessive expenditures of public funds for supply or maintenance of services; (2) Property deemed unsuitable by concerned agencies. Property which other public agencies concerned have investigated and found in the best interest of the public not suitable for the type of platting and development proposed; shall not be approved for subdivision unless adequate methods are formulated by the developer for meeting the problems created by subdivision of such property. (3) Land unsuitably located for subdivision. The planning commission shall not approve what it considers to be scattered or premature subdivisions of land which would endanger health, safety, or property because lack of or adverse effect on water supply, schools, proper drainage, good transportation, other public services or public funds for the supply or maintenance of such services. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-8, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-69. - Resubdividing. (a) Parcels on official tax appraisal map. Parcels which are combined or returned to acreage as shown on the official tax appraisal map shall not be resubdivided except in conformance with all provisions of these chapter. (b) Resubdivision within a residential subdivision. Lots or tracts of land within an approved residential subdivision may be further subdivided provided the newly created lots meet all requirements in this chapter and are no smaller in dimension than the average lot width and depth of all other lots within the residential subdivision. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-9, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-70. - Revisions. No change, erasure, or revision shall be made on any preliminary or final plat, nor on accompanying data sheets after approval of the director or planning commission has been endorsed in writing on the plat or sheets, unless authorization for such changes has been granted in writing by the planning commission. In no case shall the planning commission approve a revision thereof unless the fact that it is a revised plat is clearly stated thereon. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-10, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-71. - Nonresidential subdivisions. (a) Generally. If a proposed subdivision includes land that is zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, the layout of the subdivision with respect to the land shall make provision as the planning commission may require. Site plan approval and nonresidential subdivision plat approval may proceed simultaneously at the discretion of the planning commission. A nonresidential subdivision shall be subject to all the requirements of these regulations, as well as such additional standards required by the planning commission, and shall conform to the proposed land use and standards established in the comprehensive plan. (b) Standards. In addition to the principles and standards in this chapter, which are appropriate to the planning of all subdivisions, the applicant shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the planning commission that the street, parcel, and block pattern proposed is specifically adapted to the uses anticipated and takes into account other uses in the vicinity. The following principles and standards shall be observed: (1) All proposed industrial parcels shall be suitable in area and dimension to the types of industrial development anticipated. (2) Street rights-of-way and pavement shall be adequate to accommodate the type and volume of traffic anticipated to be generated thereupon. (3) Special requirements may be imposed by the county with respect to street, curb, gutter, and sidewalk design and construction. (4) Special requirements may be imposed by the county with respect to the installation of public utilities, including water, sewer, and stormwater drainage. (5) Every effort shall be made to protect adjacent residential areas from potential nuisance from a proposed commercial or industrial subdivision, including the provision of extra depth in parcels backing up on existing or potential residential development and provisions for a permanently landscaped buffer strip as defined in section 34-631. (6) Streets carrying nonresidential traffic, especially truck traffic, shall not normally be extended to the boundaries of adjacent existing or potential areas. (Ord. No. 48, § 4-11, 1-9-2003) Secs. 34-72—34-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURE FOR PLAT APPROVAL
Sec. 34-101. - Procedure. (a) Subdivision defined. A "subdivision" is the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots or building sites. "Subdivision" also relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. The term shall also include the opening of a new street or road. The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots meet the standards of the county subdivision regulations are not included within this definition. (b) Steps for approval. The procedure for review, consideration and approval of a subdivision plat consists of two separate steps, which are: (1) Preliminary subdivision plat (step 1); (2) Final subdivision plat (step 2). (c) Official submission dates. For the purpose of this chapter, the date of the meeting of the planning commission at which the hearing of a preliminary plat or public meeting on approval of a final subdivision plat, including any adjourned date thereof, is closed, accordingly shall constitute the official submission date of the plat on which the statutory period required for formal approval, conditional approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat or final plat submittal shall commence to run. (d) Compliance with plat requirements. Approval of all steps is contingent upon full compliance with the plat requirements specified in sections 34-131—34-141 and 34-171—34-178. Step 1 shall be completed prior to making any street improvement or installing any utilities. Step 2 shall be completed prior to the sale of any lots in the proposed subdivision. (e) Exemptions from preliminary plat requirements. (1) A subdivision which will have four or fewer lots fronting on a road or street shown on the official road map of the county; provided no new street, community water system, or community sewer system is required and provided no new lots have a depth greater than 2.5 times the width, shall be exempted from the requirements of a preliminary plat approval. The subdivision shall be required to obtain a recording and approval certificate as a final plat. (2) Any division of land to heirs or any division of land pursuant to a judicial partition, or any division of land occurring from the foreclosure of a deed of trust; provided, however, that such exemption shall not require the county to issue permits if the resulting lots or parcels fail to meet any applicable regulations of the local jurisdiction. A plat meeting this exemption must have the following notation on the plat: "This final plat is exempt from the preliminary plat requirements, however, the lots shown on the plat are for estate planning purposes only, do not meet the minimum requirements of the Land Development Ordinance of Lincoln County, and no building permit will be issued for development on these lots as they are shown on this plat. ________, 20___. ___________ Chair, Lincoln County Planning Commission (Ord. No. 48, § 5-1, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-102. - Preapplication. Prior to the review, consideration and approval of a preliminary plat by the planning commission, the subdivider may schedule an initial meeting with the director of planning and zoning to discuss the proposed development. The developer may offer a simple sketch plan for comments from the director if desired. The purpose of the meeting is to assist the subdivider with questions he may have prior to extensive site planning necessary for the preparation of the preliminary plat and enable the subdivider to become familiar with the regulations affecting the land to be subdivided. Recommendations received from the director of planning and zoning concerning the proposed development or the sketch plan do not authorize the developer to begin the proposed construction or improvements. (Ord. No. 48, § 5-2, 1-9-2003) Secs. 34-103—34-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PRELIMINARY PLAT
Sec. 34-131. - Application procedure. (a) A complete application for preliminary approval of a subdivision plat shall be submitted to the director of planning and zoning together with the appropriate fee as determined by the board of commissioners. The director shall not accept a fee until an application has been completed according to the requirements of this section. (b) No less than five copies of the plat of the subdivision shall be submitted and shall be such as to meet the minimum requirements contained in this chapter. Also, one copy shall be returned to the owner or proprietor of the subdivision or his representative with the date of the approval or disapproval noted thereon. The sheet size shall not exceed 18 by 24 inches nor be less than 8 ½ by 11 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. Each copy shall have original signatures in a contrasting color. (c) Any preliminary plat submitted to the planning commission shall contain the name, phone number and address of the subdivider (or subdivider's designee); and no preliminary plat shall be approved by the planning commission without full compliance with the requirements of the preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall be prepared by a licensed land surveyor, registered professional engineer or licensed landscape architect. (d) Additional copies of the plat and supplemental information may be requested by the planning commission. The above-mentioned copies shall be distributed to any other person or agency as deemed necessary by the planning commission. The person or agency to which a copy of the preliminary plat is directed shall indicate any desired changes or comments on the plat and submit the plat to the planning commission prior to formal approval of the preliminary plat. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-1, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-132. - Public hearing. After acceptance of a complete application for preliminary plat approval, including all accompanying material, by the director, the planning commission shall call a public hearing for the next scheduled meeting of the commission to be held at least 30 days after the date of the application. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-2, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-133. - Public notice. Public notice of the hearing on the application for preliminary plat approval shall be given at least 15, but not more than 45 days prior to the scheduled public hearing. The director shall file a notice of public hearing which shall be published once in the newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. Such notice shall identify the property affected. Additionally, at least 15 days before the scheduled public hearing, the director shall post, in a conspicuous place on the property a sign at least two feet by three feet in size. It shall set forth the time, place and purpose of the public hearing before the planning commission. Acts of vandalism or natural occurrences limiting the effectiveness of notice by a sign posted on the property shall not invalidate any proceedings or action taken under this article. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-3, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-134. - Preliminary plat approval. (a) The planning commission shall approve, disapprove or approve with modification, the preliminary plat within 45 days after the date it is presented at the public hearing. If approved, the planning commission shall indicate so in writing, stating the conditions of such approval, if any, or if disapproved, the planning commission shall express in writing its disapproval and its reasons therefore. Failure of the planning commission to act within 45 days after formal submission of the preliminary plat and the public hearing is held, shall be deemed to constitute approval, and certificate to that effect shall be issued by the planning commission on demand; provided, however, that the subdivider may waive this requirement and consent in writing to the extension of such period. (b) Preliminary approval of the subdivision plat shall be noted on the plat and certified by the planning commission. Also, noted shall be the date on which the planning commission granted preliminary approval and the date of written notification to the subdivider or subdivider's authorized agent. (c) Approval of a preliminary subdivision plat shall not constitute approval of the final subdivision plat. Preliminary approval shall constitute approval of the proposed widths and alignments of streets and the dimensions and shapes of lots subject to the final approval of the county health department. Application for approval of the final record plat will be considered only after the requirements for final plat approval as specified in this chapter have been fulfilled and after all other specified conditions have been met. Upon approval of the preliminary subdivision plat by the planning commission, the subdivider may proceed to comply with the other requirements of these regulations and the preparation of the final subdivision plat. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-4, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-135. - Standards for approval of preliminary plats. (a) No preliminary plat of a proposed subdivision shall be approved by the planning commission unless the applicant proves by clear and convincing evidence that: (1) Definite provision has been made for a water supply system that is sufficient in terms of quantity, dependability, and quality to provide an appropriate supply of water for the type of subdivision proposed; (2) If a public sewage system is proposed, adequate provision has been made for such a system and, if other methods of sewage disposal are proposed, that such systems will comply with federal, state, and local laws and regulations; (3) All proposed streets on the preliminary plat are in conformity with adopted design standards, if any, and existing and proposed public street improvements; (4) All areas of the proposed subdivision which may involve soil or topographical conditions presenting hazards or requiring special precautions have been identified by the subdivider and that the proposed uses of these areas are compatible with such conditions; (5) The subdivider has the financial ability to complete the proposed subdivision in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations; (6) There is not other available subdivided land in the jurisdiction of the county that would be more suitable for the applicant's proposed uses of the subdivision; (7) The proposed subdivision will not result in the scattered subdivision of land that leaves undeveloped parcels of land lacking urban services between developed parcels; (8) The subdivider has taken every effort to mitigate the impact of the proposed subdivision on public health, safety, and welfare. (b) The planning commission is authorized to disapprove the preliminary plat even though the land proposed for subdivision is zoned for the use to which the proposed subdivision will be put and the proposed use is consistent with the comprehensive plan. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-5, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-136. - Public improvements. The planning commission may require that all public improvements be installed and dedicated prior to the signing of the final subdivision plat. If the planning commission does not require that all public improvements be installed and dedicated prior to signing of the final subdivision plat, the planning commission shall require that the applicant execute a subdivision improvement agreement and provide security for the agreement as provided in section 34-311(3). The planning commission shall require the applicant to indicate on the plat all roads and public utility improvements which shall be required to be established or extended, and any other special requirements deemed necessary by the planning commission in order to conform the subdivision plat to the county comprehensive plan. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-6, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-137. - Effective period of preliminary plat approval. The approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one year from the date that the preliminary plat is approved by the planning commission, at the end of which time the applicant must have submitted a final subdivision plat for approval. If a subdivision plat is not submitted for final approval within the one-year period, the preliminary approval shall be null and void, and the applicant shall be required to submit a new plat for preliminary plat review subject to the then existing zoning restrictions and subdivision regulations. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-7, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-138. - Conformance to zoning and subdivision regulations. Every preliminary plat shall conform to existing zoning regulations and subdivision regulations applicable at the time that the proposed preliminary plat is submitted for the approval of the planning commission unless the planning commission has taken official action toward amending the applicable zoning and subdivision regulations and the applicant has reason to know of that action. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-8, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-139. - Grading of site prior to final approval. Subsequent to preliminary approval the developer may apply for an erosion and sediment control permit from the director of planning and zoning or such other agency or person as the planning commission shall direct, and upon receipt of the permit may commence construction to the grades and elevations required by the approved preliminary plat. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-9, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-140. - Preliminary plat requirements. The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet and meet the minimum standards of design set forth in these regulations and shall include the following information: (1) General conditions: a. Full name of proposed subdivision. b. Name, address, and telephone number of petitioner and architect, surveyor, engineer or designer. c. All names and addresses of all property owners of the site. d. All names and addresses of adjoining subdivision or all deed record owners of the land adjacent to the site. e. Date, scale, and north arrow on map. f. Location or vicinity map at a scale of not less than one inch equals one mile tying the subdivision into the present road system and relating the subdivision to its surrounding area. g. Acreage to be subdivided. h. A written legal description (metes and bounds with all bearing and distances) of the acreage to be subdivided. i. Proper identification of the boundaries of the tract to be subdivided with all bearings and distances indicated. The boundary survey shall be to such a degree of accuracy that the error of closure is 1:7,500 or greater. (2) Existing conditions: a. Topographic map on a scale of one inch representing 100 feet or less and contour intervals of five feet or less, showing major watercourses, marshes, rock outcrops, wooded areas, and other outstanding features. b. Zoning district classification of land to be subdivided and adjoining land. c. In case of resubdivision, a copy of the existing plat with proposed resubdivision superimposed thereon. d. Location of natural features such as streams, lakes, swamps, slopes, soils, significant wildlife habitats, woodlands, farmland, historic, archeological and cultural features, groundwater recharge areas and land subject to flood based on a 100-year flood frequency on the property to be subdivided. e. Location of existing adjoining property lines and existing buildings on the property to be subdivided. f. Location and right-of-way of streets, roads, railroads and utility lines either on or adjacent to the property to be subdivided. Specify whether utility lines are in easements or rights-of-way and show location of poles or towers. g. Size and location of existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the street or within the right-of-way of streets or roads adjoining the tract. Grades and invert elevations of sewers shall be shown. h. The acreage of each drainage area affecting the proposed subdivision. i. All elevations shall refer to mean sea level datum where public water and/or public sewers are to be installed. j. Location of county boundary lines and city boundary lines (if applicable). k. Location of any wetlands situated on the property to be subdivided. l. Soil survey for each proposed building site. (3) Proposed conditions. a. Layout of streets, roads, alleys, public crosswalks, with widths, road names, or designations, grades and cross sections. b. Profile of proposed streets showing natural and finished grades with percent of grade slope. c. Detailed layout of all lots, including building setback lines, scaled dimensions on lots, utility easements with width and use. d. Construction drawings of sanitary sewers (if applicable) with grade, pipe size, location of manholes, and points of discharge and percolation tests, soil borings and wells as specified by the health department. e. Construction drawings of storm sewer system with grade, pipe size, and location of outlet. Storm sewers shall be sized to accommodate runoff from a ten-year frequency rainfall. If no stormwater system is constructed, drawings showing the natural handling of stormwater runoff through swales, and other natural techniques. Certification of no additional stormwater runoff after construction. f. Plans of all drainage provisions, retaining walls, curbing, planting, anti-erosion devices or other protective devices to be constructed in connection with, or as a part of the proposed work together with a map showing the drainage area of land tributary to the site and estimated runoff of the area served by any drains. g. Construction drawings of water supply system with pipe size and location of hydrants and valves. h. Designation of all land, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for public use. i. Designation of proposed use of all lots to be used for other than single-family residential. j. Proposed major contour changes to areas where substantial cut and/or fill is to be done. k. A timing schedule indicating the anticipated starting and completion dates of the development sequence and the time of exposure of each area prior to the completion of effective erosion and sediment control measures. l. Total number of lots, total acreage, total length and width of new streets. (Ord. No. 48, § 6-10, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-141. - Certificate of preliminary approval. A certificate of approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: "This preliminary plat was given preliminary approval by the Lincoln County Planning Commission on ________, 20___. ___________ Chair, Lincoln County Planning Commission (Ord. No. 48, § 6-11, 1-9-2003) Secs. 34-142—34-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FINAL PLAT
Sec. 34-171. - Application procedure. (a) Five copies of the application for final approval of the subdivision plat shall be submitted to the director of planning and zoning with the appropriate fee as determined by the board of commissioners. The director shall examine the final plat to determine if it meets all requirements of this chapter, conforms to the approved preliminary plat, has approval of the county health department, design of the roads has been approved by the county engineer or other designated official, and whether streets and easements have been dedicated or qualify for dedication. (b) The director of planning and zoning shall forward the application for final plat approval to the planning commission, if necessary, at least 30 days prior to a regular meeting of the planning commission in order that the required minimum 15 days public notice be given. (c) The application for final plat approval shall be accompanied by all formal irrevocable offers of dedication to the public of all streets, local government uses, utilities, parks, and easements, in a form approved by the county attorney; and the subdivision plat shall be marked with a notation indicating the formal offers of dedication as follows: The owner, or his representative, hereby irrevocably offers for dedication to Lincoln County all the streets, local government uses, easements, parks, and required utilities shown on the subdivision plat and construction plans in accordance with an irrevocable offer of dedication dated ________, and recorded with the Lincoln County Clerk of Courts. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-1, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-172. - Endorsement of health authorities. The final subdivision plat shall be properly endorsed by the county health department with respect to all sewer or septic tank and water facilities and that they comply with all rules, regulations, and requirements of the county, the state and federal authorities. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-2, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-173. - Final plat determination. (a) If significant changes from the preliminary plat have been made, the director shall schedule the final subdivision plat determination for the next available regular meeting agenda of the planning commission. Public notice of final plat determination shall be given at least 15, but not more than 45 days prior to the next available regular meeting. The director shall file a written notice which shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the announcement. Such notice shall identify the property affected. The cost of such newspaper notice shall be paid by the applicant for final plat approval. (b) At the meeting, the planning commission shall approve, disapprove or approve with modification, the final plat. If approved, the planning commission shall indicate so in writing, stating the conditions of such approval, if any, or if disapproved, the planning commission shall express in writing its disapproval and its reasons therefore. If the planning commission does not act within 45 days of the official submission of the final plat to the planning commission the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued by the planning commission on demand. (c) Final plat determination may be approved by the director provided there are no major changes from the approved preliminary plat. Determination shall be made by the director of planning and permits as to whether significant changes from the preliminary plat have been made. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-3, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-174. - Signing of plat. (a) When a subdivision improvement agreement and security are required, the planning commission shall endorse approval on the final plat after the agreement and security have been approved by the planning commission, and all the conditions of the resolution pertaining to the final plat have been satisfied. (b) When installation of improvements is required prior to recordation of the final plat, the planning commission shall endorse approval on the final plat after all conditions of the resolution have been satisfied and all improvements satisfactorily completed. There shall be written evidence that the required public facilities have been installed in a manner satisfactory to the county as shown by a certification signed by the planning commission and county attorney stating that the necessary dedication of public lands and improvements have been accomplished. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-4, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-175. - Recording. If approved, a plat shall be recorded in the clerk's office of the superior court of the county upon authentication by the planning commission, within 60 days after final approval thereof. Otherwise, such approval shall be withdrawn by the planning commission and the superior court shall not file or record a plat of a subdivision until such plat has been approved by the planning commission. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-5, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-176. - Plat approval not acceptance of dedication offers. The approval of a plat does not constitute acceptance by the county of the offer of dedication of any streets, sidewalks, parks, public facilities or other ground shown on a plat. However, the county may accept such offer of dedication by resolution of the planning commission or implicitly by maintenance of such facilities. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-6, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-177. - Distribution. As previously stated, five prints shall be submitted to the planning commission with other required materials comprising the final plat. The sheet size shall not exceed 18 by 24 inches nor be less than 8½ by 11 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. After approval, two prints shall be returned to the owner or proprietor of the subdivision for recordation in the precise form as approved. Three prints with recording information included thereon, shall be retained and distributed as follows: (1) Tax assessor, one print. (2) Clerk of superior court, one print. (3) Director, one print. (Ord. No. 48, § 7-7, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-178. - Final plat requirements. If the final plat is drawn in two or more sections, each section shall be accompanied by a key map showing the location of the several sections. The final plat shall contain the following specific information: (1) Name of owner of record. (2) Name of subdivision, date, north arrow and graphic scale. (3) Name, registration number and seal of registered land surveyor, unless the surveyor is an elected official. (4) Names of county in which subdivision is located and location map. (5) Sufficient data to determine readily and reproduce accurately on the ground the location, bearing, length and width of every street and alley line, lot line, easement, boundary line and building line, whether curved or straight. This shall include the radius, point of tangency and other data for curved property lines and curved streets, to an appropriate accuracy and in conformance with good surveying practice. (6) Names of owners of record of all adjoining land and all property boundaries, watercourses, streets, easements, utilities and other such improvements, which cross or form any boundary line of the tract being subdivided. (7) Exact boundaries and original property line of the tract, determined by a field surveyor, shown with bearings and distances. (8) Streets and alleys, rights-of-way and street names within and immediately adjoining the plat. (9) Rights-of-way of easements; location, widths and purposes, or any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. (10) A statement, either on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants. (11) Lot lines, minimum building setback lines, street trees and lot and block numbers. (12) Parks, school sites or other public open spaces. (13) All dimensions shall be to the nearest 1/100 of a foot and angles to the nearest second. (14) Accurate description of the location of all monuments and markers. Markers shall be metal pipe or rods at least one-half inch in diameter and 24 inches in length. (15) A final plat shall be a good legible print, blue, white or other commercial print reproduced from a tracing made in India ink on a commercial grade of tracing cloth, tracing film, or tracing paper with a sheet size of not more than 18 by 24 inches, leaving a two-inch binding edge. Where more than one sheet is required, an index map shall be required on the same size sheet. (16) Utility easements by widths and locations to include: a. Water; b. Gas; c. Sanitary sewer; d. Storm drainage; e. Electrical lines; f. Telephone lines. (17) The following signed certificates shall appear on the final plat which is submitted to the planning commission by the subdivider: a. Certificate of approval for recording: (To be placed on an original of the approved final plat by the planning commission and returned to the subdivider for recording): "The subdivision plat known as ___________, has been found to comply with the Lincoln County Land Development Ordinance and was approved by the Planning Commission on the _____ day of________, 20___, for the recording in the office of Clerk of the Superior Court of Lincoln County, Georgia. ___________ Lincoln County Planning Commission Chair b.
