(Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-669. - Collocation guidelines. It is the intent that new antennas where possible shall be collocated on existing towers and poles, placed on existing buildings, or be within an existing support structure. Any additional users collocating on existing communication towers shall require review and approval. All new towers shall be designed to structurally accommodate the maximum number of additional users technically practicable. Applications for a new tower must include a letter of intent to lease excess space on the tower structure and to lease additional excess land on the tower site, as provided in section 34-668(1)n. When a communication tower is proposed, evidence shall be provided demonstrating that no other tower is available, as directed in section 34-664. (1) A reasonable pro rata charge may be made for collocation, consistent with an appropriate sharing of construction, financing and maintenance costs. Fees may also be charged for any structural or RF changes necessitated by such shared use. Such sharing shall be a condition of if approval is granted. a. The applicant shall describe what range of charges are reasonably expected to be assessed against shared users. b. The applicant shall base charges on generally accepted accounting principles and shall explain the elements included in the charge. (2) Collocation is not precluded simply because a reasonable fee for shared use is charged, or because of reasonable costs necessary to adapt the existing and proposed uses to a shared tower. The director, commission and the governing body may consider expert testimony to determine whether the fee and costs are reasonable. Costs exceeding new tower development are presumed unreasonable. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-670. - Applications for collocation or modification of a communications facility entitled to streamlined processing. (a) Eligibility. Applicants that do not meet the following requirements must adhere to the application requirements in section 34-668. Applicants that meet the following requirements shall be shall be reviewed for conformance with applicable site plan and building permit requirements, including zoning and land use conformity, but shall not otherwise be subject to the issuance of additional zoning, land use, or special use permit approvals beyond the initial zoning, land use, or special permit approvals issued for such wireless support structure or wireless facility. (1) The proposed modification or collocation shall not increase the overall height or width of the wireless support structure to which the wireless facilities are to be attached; (2) The proposed modification or collocation shall not increase the dimensions of the equipment compound initially approved by the local governing authority; (3) The proposed modification or collocation shall comply with applicable conditions of approval, if any, applied to the initial wireless facilities and wireless support structure, as well as any subsequently adopted amendments to such conditions of approval; and (4) The proposed modification or collocation shall not exceed the applicable weight limits for the wireless support structure, as demonstrated by a letter from a structural engineer licensed to practice in this state. (b) A complete application must include the following: (1) Engineer's certification on interference. A certified letter prepared by a radio frequency engineer licensed to practice in Georgia that the proposed communications facility/facilities will not interfere with public safety emergency communications. (2) Site plan. Site plan(s) to scale specifying the zoning district and adjacent land uses, as well as the location of the proposed communications facility, guy anchors (if any), transmission building and/or other accessory uses, lighting, access, parking, fences, and landscaped areas. (3) Statement of compliance with requirements as laid out in subsection (a) of this section. (4) Application fee. In order to cover the actual cost to the county of reviewing these applications and obtaining expert opinion and studies, the following fees are hereby established. For those applications requiring administrative approval, a fee of $500.00 shall be paid at the time of application. (c) Review timeline. Within 90 calendar days of the date an application for modification or collocation of wireless facilities is filed with the local governing authority, unless another date is specified in a written agreement between the local governing authority and the applicant, the local governing authority shall: (1) Make its final decision to approve or disapprove the application; and (2) Advise the applicant in writing of its final decision. (d) Within 30 calendar days of the date an application for modification or collocation is filed with the local governing authority, the local governing authority shall determine if it is a complete application and, if it determines the application is not a complete application, notify the applicant in writing of any information required to complete such application. To the extent additional information is required to complete the application, the time required by the applicant to provide such information shall not be counted toward the 90 calendar day review period set forth in subsection (c) of this section. Information requested to complete the application may only include the documents, information, and fees specifically enumerated in the local governing authority's existing regulations, ordinances, and forms pertaining to the location, construction, collocation, modification, or operation of wireless facilities. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-671. - Financial assurance. (a) Financial assurance required. An applicant for a proposed communication tower or antenna shall provide a financial assurance as specified in this section as a condition of permit issuance. The director will determine the reasonable cost to remove the communications facility and restore the facility site to the condition that it was in before construction and installation of the facility. An applicant must provide financial assurance in that amount before a permit will be issued. A financial assurance must be irrevocable and not cancelable, except by the county. (b) Duration of financial assurance. Each form of financial assurance must remain valid for the duration of the permit and for at least six months following the termination, cancellation, or revocation of the permit. (c) Form of financial assurance. Financial assurance must be provided in one or more of the following forms: (1) A deposit with the county. The deposit will not earn interest. (2) A surety bond issued by an admitted surety insurer. (3) A standby letter of credit, naming the county as beneficiary, issued by a bank authorized to do business in the state. The letter of credit must be payable within seven business days, upon demand by the county. (4) An escrow account comprised of any of the following: cash; a negotiable bond of the United States or any state, county, or municipality endorsed by the applicant and rated "A" or "A2" or higher by a nationally-recognized bond rating organization; or a negotiable certificate of deposit in a depository insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The value of any of those will be based on the then-current value, not the value at maturity. The financial instruments held in escrow must be payable within seven business days, upon demand by county. (5) A renewable bond, or any other financial assurance or security acceptable to the director. (d) Substitution of financial assurance. (1) Substitution permitted. At any time during the term of a permit, a permittee may replace its financial assurance with another form of financial assurance authorized under this section. After receiving a request to replace its financial assurance, and after the permittee provides the new financial assurance to the county, the county will return any deposit, or authorize the cancellation or revocation of any other financial assurance being replaced. (2) Substitution required. If, during the term of the permit, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or another governmental entity becomes the receiver or conservator of the issuer of a financial assurance, or the issuer files for bankruptcy or dissolves, the county may request that the permittee provide a new financial assurance authorized under this section. Within 30 days after that request, a permittee must provide a new financial assurance, and, after it is provided, the county will cancel the financial assurance being replaced. If a permittee does not provide a new financial assurance within 30 days after county's request, the permit will be suspended until the new financial assurance is provided. (e) County's use of financial assurance. After providing notice to the permittee, the county may draw upon and use a financial assurance to remove an abandoned facility, as provided by section 34-673. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-672. - Appeals. Appeals shall be conducted as directed in section 34-381. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-673. - Removal of antennas and towers. (a) Annual report certifying continued operation . The owners of all communications facilities operated within the county shall file an annual report with the director. Said report shall be filed on or before the 31st day of December each year, and shall include the following: (1) Certification that the communications facility is currently in use, and if not in use, the date the communications facility ceased being in use. (2) A report from a licensed professional engineer or other qualified industry expert that the communications facility structure meets or exceeds all relevant federal and state requirements. (3) A report by a radio frequency engineer or other appropriate industry expert that the communications facility is in compliance with current FCC radio emission standards as well as the terms of their federal license. (4) An updated, current inventory of the owner's existing communications facilities sites within the county. (b) Abandonment. Any antenna or tower that is not operated for a continuous period of 12 months shall be considered abandoned, and the owner of such antenna or tower shall remove same within 90 days of receipt of notice from the director notifying the owner of such abandonment. If such antenna or tower is not removed within said time period, the county may remove such antenna or tower utilizing the owner's financial assurance as provided for in this section or place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. If there are two or more users of a single tower, then this provision shall not become effective until all users cease using the tower. (c) Lack of maintenance. All towers and antennas shall be maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable building and technical codes so as to ensure the structural integrity of such towers. If upon inspection by the director such tower is determined not to comply with the code standards or to constitute a danger to persons or property, then upon notice being provided to the owner of the tower and the owner of the property if such owner is different, such owners shall have 30 days to bring such tower into compliance. In the event such tower or antenna is not brought into compliance within 30 days, the county may provide notice to the owners requiring the tower or antenna to be removed. In the event such tower or antenna is not removed within 30 days of receipt of such notice, the county may remove such antenna or tower utilizing the owner's financial assurance as provided for in this section or place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. Delay by the county in taking action shall not in any way waive the county's right to take action. The county may pursue all legal remedies available to it to insure that communication towers and antenna not in compliance with the code standards or which constitute danger to persons or property are brought into compliance or removed. The county may seek to have the tower or antenna removed regardless of the owners' or operator's intent to operate the tower or antenna and regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Sec. 34-674. - Variances. Communication towers or antennas not in conformance with the regulations listed in section 34-665(a) may only be built after approval of a variance by the commission in accordance with sections 34-381—34-385. (Ord. of 12-8-2016) Secs. 34-675—34-700. - Reserved. ARTICLE XXI. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 34-701. - Off-street parking. (a) Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide regulations to ensure safe and efficient circulation of vehicles and pedestrians on public and private streets and to minimize nuisances from on-street parking. (b) General requirements. For the purpose of this section, the following general requirements are specified: (1) Combination of required parking space. The required space for any number of separate uses may be combined in one lot but the required space assigned to each use may not be assigned to another use, except where the parking space required for churches or other assembly halls whose peak attendance will be at night, on Sunday, or otherwise does not coincide with an adjacent use, said required parking may be assigned to the adjacent use. (2) Proximity of off-street parking spaces to use. All required parking for all uses shall be provided on the same lot as the principal use. (3) Location on other property. If the required automobile parking spaces cannot be provided on the same lot where the principal use is located, the board of commissioners may permit such space to be provided on other off-street property within 300 feet of the building (or open use area) it is to serve, provided, however, that no required parking spaces may be located across any major street from the use it is intended to serve. (4) Requirements for design of parking lots. a. Except for parcels of land devoted to one- family and two-family residential uses, all areas devoted to off-street parking shall be so designed and be of such size that no vehicle is required to back into a public street to obtain access. b. Each parking space shall be not less than 162 square feet in area; nine feet wide by 18 feet long, except that handicapped spaces shall comply with the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act. _____ (c) Parking space requirements for all use zones. In addition to the number of spaces required by the Americans with Disabilities Act, off-street automobile storage or parking space shall be provided with vehicular access to a public street and it shall be equal to or greater than the minimum requirements for the specific use set forth below:
_____ (d) Uses not specified. In the case of a use not specifically mentioned in subsection (c) of this section, the requirements for off-street parking facilities shall be determined by the board of commissioners. Such determination shall be based upon the requirements set forth for the most comparable use specified in subsection (c) of this section. (e) Reduction of spaces. The planning commission may, at their discretion, reduce the minimum number of parking spaces required for a specific use by subsection (c) of this section, provided that sufficient evidence is presented justifying the need for reduction in the requirements and every effort has been made to provide off-street parking in accordance with the stipulations of this amendment. (f) Restriction on use of required parking. The required off-street parking shall be for employees, occupants, clients and visitors. It shall be limited in use to temporary storage of motor vehicles with current license plates. The storage of merchandise or motor vehicles for sale, the servicing or repairing of vehicles or equipment and regular truck loading and unloading thereon is prohibited. (Ord. No. 48, § 22-1, 1-9-2003) _____ Sec. 34-702. - Off-street loading. (a) Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide regulations to ensure the adequate provision of off-street loading and unloading space as required by this chapter. (b) General requirements for off-street loading and unloading space. Every building or structure or lot used for business, trade, or industry shall provide space as established in this chapter for the loading and unloading of vehicles off the public street or alley. Such space shall have access to a public street or alley. Such space shall be arranged so that no vehicle is required to back into a public street, road or highway in order to leave the premises. Each loading space provided shall be an area 12 feet by 45 feet with a 14-foot height clearance where uses require trailer-truck loading or ten feet by 25 feet with a height clearance of 14 feet for uses not requiring trailer-truck loading. All loading spaces shall be located so as to contain adequate maneuvering room to permit convenient access to the loading space. A sufficient number of loading spaces shall be provided as follows:
(Ord. No. 48, § 22-2, 1-9-2003) _____ Secs. 34-703—34-730. - Reserved. ARTICLE XXII. - AMENDMENTS
Sec. 34-731. - Generally. The board of commissioners may amend, supplement or change the regulations set forth in this chapter or the boundaries of the zoning districts established on the official zoning map. (1) No amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been initiated by either the board of commissioners or the planning commission, the property owner, or an individual who has the owner's power of attorney authorizing him to act, or a request signed by 60 percent of the property owners who hold not less than 60 percent of the affected land. (2) As used in this article, the term "amendment" means both a change to the "official zoning map" and a change to the text of this chapter unless otherwise indicated. All proposed amendments shall first be submitted to the planning commission who shall conduct a public hearing and shall make a written recommendation to the board of commissioners. The power to approve and enact an amendment rests solely within the legislative discretion of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-1, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-732. - Procedure. (a) Application for amendment. All proposed amendments shall be initiated by an application with the director on forms provided by the county. A standard fee shall be paid with the application for amendment of these regulations may be in the form of a proposal for amendment of the text of regulations or a proposal for amendment of the zoning map. (b) Notification of public hearing; property in violation prohibited. Within 15 days after receiving the application, the director shall in writing inform the applicant of the date on which a public hearing will be held to consider the zoning change. No application will be accepted from any person regarding any property that is in violation of this chapter. If the property, at the time of application, which is the subject of an amendment or any other action of the board of commissioners, is found to be in violation of this chapter, then the board of commissioners will not accept and/or process any application from that applicant until the applicant voluntarily removes or changes the cause of the violation or ceases to be in violation. The applicant must then notify the director that he is no longer in violation and obtain a release from the director as to the violation. Once released, the board of commissioners will then accept the application for amendment of this chapter. (c) Erection of sign. Upon receiving an application for a map amendment and establishing the date of the public hearing concerning the petitioned request, the director shall erect in a conspicuous place on the property in question or on the right-of-way of the nearest public road if the property does not front a public road a sign giving notice of both the existing zoning district in which the property is located and the requested change and the scheduled date and place for the public hearing. (d) Referral to planning commission. After acceptance of application for amendment, the director shall transmit a copy thereof to the planning commission for its review during the scheduled public hearing and recommendation. It will study the proposed amendment and determine if it meets the standards as enumerated in section 34-733. Once the public hearing has been conducted in accordance with section 34-736, the planning commission shall make a written recommendation to the board of commissioners stating its approval or disapproval of the requested zoning change. Such recommendation shall be made by the planning commission within 45 days of the public hearing or the requested zoning change shall be deemed to have been recommended for approval by the planning commission. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-2, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-733. - Zoning standards. (a) The exercise of the zoning power of the county shall constitute an effort to balance the interest of the community in promoting the public health, safety, morality and general welfare against the right of property owners to the unrestricted use of their property. The following factors shall be considered by the planning commission when reviewing and making its written recommendation and by the board of commissioners when making a decision whether to approve or deny the requested amendment. These factors are determined to be relevant in balancing the interest in promoting the public health, safety, morality and general welfare against the right to the unrestricted use of the property: (1) Whether the proposed amendment would allow a use that is generally suitable for the site compared to other possible uses and the uses and zoning of adjacent and nearby properties; (2) Whether the proposed amendment would adversely affect the economic value or the uses of adjacent and nearby properties; (3) Whether the property to be affected by the proposed amendment can be used as currently zoned; (4) Whether the proposed amendment, if adopted, would result in a use which would or could cause an excessive or burdensome use of existing streets, schools, sewers, water resources, police and fire protection or other utilities; (5) Whether there are other conditions or transitional patterns affecting the use and development of the property sought to be rezoned, if applicable, which give ground for either approval or disapproval of the proposed amendment. (b) The county shall consider any proposed amendment properly initiated in light of the factors set forth in this section. In evaluating the factors set forth in this section, it shall be the policy of the county to exercise its zoning power in conformity with the policy and intent of the county comprehensive plan insofar as that plan is current in its application to the specific property that is the subject of the proposed amendment. It is further the policy of the county to exercise the zoning power for purposes of assuring the compatibility of use of adjacent and nearby properties and the preservation of the economic value of adjacent and nearby properties while enabling a reasonable use of all property. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-3, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-734. - Public hearing. Before making a written recommendation to the board of commissioners, the planning commission shall hold a public hearing thereon. A public hearing shall be conducted at the time and place specified by the planning commission and as set forth in the public notice described in section 34-735. The purpose of such hearing shall be to present to the public the proposed zoning amendment, and to receive comments thereon from the public. The board of commissioners shall consider the proceedings and comments of such hearing on the proposed zoning amendment in making a final decision on whether to approve or deny the amendment application. The planning commission shall prescribe the rules of order for its deliberations on matters with which it is charged under this chapter, and the rules of order shall be consistent with the general requirements and purposes set forth in this article and other general laws of the state concerning conduct of proceedings of public commissions, bodies and governmental units. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-4, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-735. - Public notice. (a) Public notice of the hearing on a proposed amendment to the zoning ordinance of the county shall be given as set forth in subsection (b). (b) At least 15, but not more than 45 days prior to the date set by the planning commission for the hearing, a written notice shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. Such notice shall contain a summary of the proposed amendment, if a text amendment, and in the case of a map amendment, the location of the property, its area, name or owner, and the proposed change or classification. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-5, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-736. - Conduct of hearings. The following policies and procedures shall govern the conduct of public hearings under this chapter: (1) The hearing shall be convened by the chair of the planning commission at the time and place scheduled. (2) The chair shall open any hearing with an explanation of the purpose of the hearing and a description of the general rules for the conduct of the hearing. The chair or his designee may describe the authority and role of the planning commission in any zoning decision. (3) The chair shall review the procedures for holding the public hearing which shall be as follows: a. No person may speak until recognized by the chair. Upon rising to speak, the person recognized must first state his name and address. b. One or two spokespersons will be allowed two minutes to express opinions of the proposed zoning revisions; provided, however, that the spokespersons shall speak no longer than an aggregate of ten minutes. c. Any remark amounting to an attack on the character or personal integrity of another individual, or comment not factually supportable, or comment in the form of an emotional outburst, shall be irrelevant to the purpose of any hearing and may be ruled out of order. d. Additional persons will be recognized in accordance with the procedure set forth in this section for the purpose of addressing additional issues and making additional points, but no speaker shall be allowed to address points which have already been thoroughly discussed. e. In the case of each petition for amendment to the zoning ordinance, the chair shall allow the applicant, or the agent for the applicant, to speak first and to present the arguments of the applicant in favor of the proposed amendment. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-6, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-737. - Official action by the board of commissioners. (a) Once the planning commission submits a recommendation to the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners at a regular meeting may take action approving or rejecting the proposal at that meeting, or the board of commissioners may table the question for consideration at its next regular meeting or a called meeting to be held no later than the next regular meeting. (b) The planning commission's role in any zoning amendment decision shall be advisory only. Any zoning amendment decision shall be made by the board of commissioners who shall either approve or disapprove the proposed zoning amendment. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-7, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-738. - Speculative rezonings/reversion. The county discourages the use of rezonings as a strategy to increase speculative land value where the applicant has no immediate intent to develop in accordance with the rezoning. Rezonings are intended to grant the applicant an opportunity to exercise appropriate alternative development options in situations where development in compliance with existing zoning is not possible or practicable, as long as the proposed uses are consistent with the comprehensive plan and the character of the surrounding area. The granting of this privilege by the county carries with it the expectation that the proposed development will occur within a reasonable period of time. Therefore, when the board of commissioners grants approval of a rezoning, the applicant should acquire a construction permit or final plat approval (whichever is applicable) and commence construction activities in compliance with that permit or approval within one year of the date upon which the rezoning is approved. Reversion: If such actions have not been taken within one year, the planning commission may initiate actions to further rezone the subject property and/or to reinstate the original zoning classification. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-8, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-739. - Appeal from decision of the board of commissioners. Appeals from the decision of the board of commissioners regarding the approval or disapproval of a zoning amendment shall be made in accordance with the judicial review in section 34-430. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-9, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-740. - Limitation on reapplication. No application for amendment of the zoning ordinance once heard by the planning commission shall be accepted for a rehearing until at least six months shall have passed since written recommendation was made by the planning commission to the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-10, 1-9-2003) Sec. 34-741. - Withdrawal without prejudice. An application may not be withdrawn or amended by the applicant after the public hearing has been advertised. However, the planning commission may by a majority vote allow an application to be withdrawn without prejudice. (Ord. No. 48, § 23-11, 1-9-2003)

div.head: Chapter 38 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; courts, ch. 26; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 50. State Law reference— Sheriffs, O.C.G.A. § 15-16-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - JAIL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 38-31—38-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - VENDING MACHINES
Sec. 38-51. - Findings. (a) Vending machines are located in jail property in the county and the question has arisen as to the legality of the spending of funds (profits) generated by the operation of these vending machines. (b) The attorney general of the state has indicated that the board of commissioners of the county is in control of all county matters. (c) To authorize the county sheriff to expend profits from vending machines, the county should give prior authorization. (Ord. No. 11, §§ 1—3, 4-11-2002) Sec. 38-52. - Authorization. (a) The county sheriff is hereby authorized and permitted to expend funds generated by the operation of vending machines located on jail property in the county, for those purposes for which the county would otherwise have to spend its funds to provide for the prisoners confined in the jail. (b) The county sheriff shall keep a written record of profits received and a written record of the expenditure of the funds and exhibit the same to the board of commissioners on the meeting date of the board of commissioners each consecutive month. (Ord. No. 11, § 4, 4-11-2002)

div.head: Chapter 42 - LIBRARY[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 42-1—42-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNTY LIBRARY DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 42-31—42-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Other boards and commissions, § 2-141 et seq.
Sec. 42-51. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Board of trustees means the Lincoln County Library Board of Trustees. (Ord. No. 15, § 1, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-52. - Created. There is hereby created and established a board of trustees for the county public library which shall be known as the "Lincoln County Library Board of Trustees." (Ord. No. 15, § 1, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-53. - Membership. The board of trustees created in this division shall consist of five members, appointed by each of the members of the board of commissioners. The five trustees shall serve in post 1, post 2, post 3, post 4 and post 5, respectively. (Ord. No. 15, § 2, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-54. - Eligibility; terms of office; vacancy and removal. (a) To be eligible for appointment to the board of trustees, a member must be a resident of the county and reside within the boundaries of the district the member shall represent. (b) Trustees shall serve for four-year staggered terms beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31 four years later, or until a successor has been appointed. (c) Vacancies in memberships of the board of trustees shall be filled in the same manner as provided for the appointment of trustees. Any person appointed as the result of a vacancy on the board shall serve the unexpired term left by the vacant member. (d) Any trustee may be removed for cause by majority vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 15, § 3, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-55. - Oath of office. No trustee shall begin to discharge his duties as a member of the board of trustees without first having taken the oath of office. (Ord. No. 15, § 4, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-56. - Organization. (a) Immediately after appointment, the membership of the board of trustees shall meet and organize by electing a chair, a vice-chair and a secretary. (b) The board of trustees shall have a written constitution and bylaws stating policy which shall be approved by the board. Such constitution and bylaws shall be drafted in accordance with the current edition of the Handbook on Constitutions, Bylaws and Contracts for Georgia Public Libraries. (c) Policies stated in the constitution of the county board may not be in conflict with the policies of the constitution of the regional board and state and federal laws and regulations. (d) All current constitutions and bylaws must be on file in the Office of Public Library Services of the Board of Regents of the University System of Georgia, and all amendments must be filed with the office immediately upon adoption. (Ord. No. 15, § 5, 2-3-1987) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 20-5-47. Sec. 42-57. - Meetings. (a) The board of trustees shall hold not less than six regular meetings each calendar year. The meetings shall be held on the second Tuesday of the months of January, March, May, July, September and November. (b) Nothing in this section shall prohibit the board of trustees from holding special meetings on the call of the chair of the board of trustees. (c) Any trustee failing to attend three consecutive meetings shall be removed, pursuant to the library systems's constitution and bylaws or the local constitution and bylaws. (Ord. No. 15, § 6, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-58. - Reports. The board of trustees shall submit a written report to the board of commissioners of its transactions, findings, proceedings and recommendations at least once a year at the first regular meeting of the commissioners following December 31 of the previous year. (Ord. No. 15, § 7, 2-3-1987) Sec. 42-59. - Duties. The board of trustees has as its primary responsibility the coordination, organization and the establishment of policies and regulations governing the use of the library, to serve the best interest of the needs and desires of the citizens of the county. The board of trustees shall advise and recommend to the board of commissioners as to the assessment and establishment of needs for the library program and use of facilities. (Ord. No. 15, § 8, 2-3-1987)

div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; land development, ch. 34; dedication and reservation of land development, § 34-281 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 70; water conservation facilities, § 70-141 et seq.; waterways, ch. 74; protection of wetlands, § 74-31 et seq. State Law reference— Protection of natural resources, environment, etc., O.C.G.A. § 12-2-8.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PROTECTION OF GROUNDWATER RECHARGE AREA[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30.
Sec. 46-31. - Title. This article shall be known as the "Groundwater Recharge Area Protection Ordinance of Lincoln County, Georgia." (Ord. No. 39, § 1.1, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-32. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aquifer means any stratum (rock layer) or zone of rock beneath the surface of the earth capable of containing or producing water from a well. Groundwater recharge area (synonymous with aquifer recharge area) means an area of the earth's surface where water infiltrated the ground, thereby replenishing the groundwater supplies within an aquifer. Pollution susceptibility means the relative vulnerability of groundwater to pollution from chemical spills, leaching of pollutants from dump sites, animal waste from agricultural operations or pollution generated by other human activities. Pollution susceptibility maps means maps prepared by the state department of natural resources that show the relative susceptibility of groundwater to pollution. Pollution susceptibility maps categorize the land areas of the state into areas of high, medium and low groundwater pollution potential. Significant groundwater recharge areas means areas mapped by the department of natural resources in Hydrologic Atlas, 18 1989 edition. Mapping of recharge areas is based on outcrop area, lithology (chemical nature and form of the rock), soil type and thickness, slope, density of lithologic contacts, geologic structure, presence of "karst" topography (sinkholes, caves and fissures associated with limestone and other carbonate rocks), and potentiometric surfaces. (Ord. No. 39, § 10, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-33. - Findings of fact. (a) In order to provide for the health, safety and welfare of the public and a healthy economic climate within the county and surrounding communities, it is essential that the quality of public drinking water be ensured. For this reason, it is necessary to protect the subsurface water resources that are contained within aquifers, which are permeable, rock strata occupying vast regions of the subsurface. These aquifers are replenished by infiltration of surface water runoff in zones of the surface known as groundwater recharge areas. (b) Groundwater is susceptible to contamination when unrestricted development occurs within significant groundwater recharge areas. It is, therefore, necessary to manage land use within groundwater recharge areas in order to ensure that pollution threats are minimized. (Ord. No. 39, § 1.2, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-34. - Objectives. The objectives of this article are to protect groundwater quality by: (1) Restricting land uses that generate, use or store dangerous pollutants in recharge areas; (2) Limiting density of development; and (3) Ensuring that any development that occurs within the recharge area shall have no adverse effect on groundwater quality. (Ord. No. 39, § 1.3, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-35. - Establishment of a groundwater recharge area district. A groundwater recharge area district is hereby established which shall correspond to all lands within the jurisdiction of the county that are mapped as significant recharge areas by the state department of natural resources in Hydrologic Atlas 18, 1989 edition. (Ord. No. 39, § 2, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-36. - Pollution susceptibility. All recharge areas within the county have low pollution susceptibility, as indicated by the state pollution susceptibility map prepared by the state department of natural resources. (Ord. No. 39, § 3, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-37. - Permit requirements. The county will approve no building permit or subdivision plan unless the permit, request or plan is in compliance with the groundwater protection standards listed in section 46-44. (Ord. No. 39, § 4, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-38. - Enforcement. The county, its agent, officers and employees shall have authority to enter upon privately owned land for the purpose of performing their duties under this article and may take or cause to be made such examinations, surveys or sampling as the county deems necessary: (1) The department of planning and zoning is hereby designated as the administrator for this article, and the code enforcement officer (CEO) is hereby designated as the enforcement officer for this article. (2) The code enforcement officer shall have authority to enforce this article; issue permits under this article; and address violations or threatened violations hereof by issuance of violation notices, administrative orders and civil and criminal actions. All costs, fees and expenses in connection with such actions may be recovered as damages against the violator. (3) Law enforcement officials or other officials having police powers shall have authority to assist the code enforcement officer in enforcement. (4) Any person who commits, takes part in or assists in any violation of any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 for each offense. Each violation shall be a separate offense and, in the case of a continuing violation, each day's continuance shall be deemed to be a separate and distinct offense. (5) The code enforcement officer shall have the authority to issue cease and desist orders in the event of any violation of this article. Cease and desist orders may be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction, as identified in section 46-45. (6) When a building or other structure has been constructed in violation of this article, the violator shall be required to remove the structure. (7) When removal of vegetative cover, excavation or fill has taken place in violation of this article, the violator shall be required to restore the affected land to its original contours and to restore vegetation, as far as practicable. (Ord. No. 39, § 4.1, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-39. - Permit review and site plan requirement. With the exception of certain exempted activities identified in section 46-40, applications for a development permit within the groundwater recharge area district shall include a site plan. The following information is required for all site plans: (1) A map, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 50 feet or other approved scale, showing all planned improvements including the width, depth and length of all existing and proposed structures, roads, watercourses and drainageways, water lines, wastewater and stormwater facilities, and utility installations, shall be provided by the applicant. (2) Location, dimensions and areas of all impervious surfaces, both existing and proposed, on the site. (3) The orientation and distance from the boundaries of the proposed site to the nearest bank of an affected perennial stream or water body. (4) Elevations of the site and adjacent lands within 200 feet of the site at contour intervals of no greater than five feet. (5) Location and detailed design of any spill and leak collection systems designed for the purpose of containing accidentally released hazardous or toxic materials. (6) Calculations of the amount of cut and fill proposed and cross sectional drawings showing existing and proposed grades in areas of fill or excavation. Elevations, horizontal scale and vertical scale must be shown on cross sectional drawings. (7) All development activities or site work conducted after approval of the site plan shall conform to the specifications of the site plan. Significant changes to the site plan that would alter the amount and velocity of stormwater runoff from the site, increase the amount of impervious surface within the development, alter the overall density of development, result in a considerable increase in the amount of excavation, fill or removal of the overall appearance of the development as proposed, can be amended only with the approval of the department of planning and zoning. Minor changes, such as the realignment of streets or minor alternations to drainage structures and other infrastructure to meet unexpected conditions are exempted from this requirement. (Ord. No. 39, § 4.2, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-40. - Exemptions to site plan requirements. The following activities and developments are exempt from the requirement for detailed site plans: (1) Single-family detached homes constructed within a subdivision of fewer than five parcels. (2) Repairs to a facility that is part of a previously approved and permitted development. (3) Construction of minor structures, such as sheds or additions to single-family residences. (Ord. No. 39, § 4.3, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-41. - Review procedures. The application shall be made to the department of planning and zoning, and will be reviewed within 14 days. The review period shall include the preparation of findings (approval, approval with conditions or disapproval) by the department of planning and zoning. The applicant will receive written notification of the findings of the department of planning and zoning. If the review process is not completed within 30 days, the application is considered to be approved. Decisions of the department of planning and zoning may be appealed to the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 39, § 4.4, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-42. - Public notice and public hearing. Public notice of permit applications, through publication in local newspapers, is required. A public hearing on the application, to be held before the board of commissioners may be scheduled if requested by a citizen. Public announcement of the hearing shall be printed in a local newspaper of general circulation at least 15 but not more than 45 days prior to the hearing. A record of the proceedings shall be made and kept on file by the county. Any person may testify at the hearing. Decisions of the board of commissioners may be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction identified in section 46-45. Sec. 46-43. - Duration of permit validity. (a) If construction described in the development permit has not commenced within 12 months from the date of issuance, the permit shall expire. (b) If construction described in the development permit is suspended or abandoned after work has commenced, the permit shall expire 12 months after the date that work ceased. (c) Written notice of pending expiration of the development permit shall be issued by the department of planning and zoning. (Ord. No. 39, § 4.6, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-44. - Groundwater protection standards. (a) Waste disposal facilities and synthetic liners. For all pollution susceptibility areas, new waste disposal facilities must have synthetic liners and leachate collection systems. (b) Waste impoundment sites. New agricultural waste impoundment sites shall be lined if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; a medium pollution susceptibility area and exceed 15 acre feet; or a low pollution susceptibility area and exceed 50 acre feet. As a minimum, the liner shall be constructed of compacted clay having a thickness of one-foot and a vertical hydraulic conductivity of less than 5 ×10 -7 cm/sec or other criteria established by the natural resource and conservation service. (c) Hazardous waste disposal facilities. No land disposal of hazardous waste shall be permitted within any significant groundwater recharge area. (d) Hazardous waste handling and storage. New facilities that handle hazardous materials of the types listed in section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (excluding underground storage tanks) and in amounts of 10,000 pounds or more on any one day, shall perform their operations on impervious surfaces and in conformance with any applicable federal spill prevention requirements and local fire code requirements. (e) Aboveground chemical and petroleum storage tanks. For all significant groundwater recharge areas, new aboveground chemical or petroleum storage tanks having a minimum of 660 gallons shall have secondary containment for 110 percent of the volume of such tanks or 110 percent of the largest tank in a cluster of tanks. Such tanks used for agricultural purposes are exempt, provided they comply with all federal requirements. (f) Minimum lot sizes for new homes. New homes served by septic tank/drain systems shall be on lots having minimum size limitations as follows, based on application of Table MT-1 of the Department of Human Resources' Manual for On-Site Sewage Management Systems ("DHR Table MT-1"). The minimums set forth in Table MT-1 may be increased further based on consideration of other factors (set forth in sections A—F) of the DHR manual. (1) One hundred fifty percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; (2) One hundred twenty-five percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area; and (3) One hundred ten percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-1 if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (g) Minimum lot sizes for new mobile home parks. New mobile home parks served by septic tank/drainfield systems shall have lots or spaces having the following size limitations as follows, based on application of Table MT-2 of the Department of Human Resources' (DHR) Manual for On-Site Sewage Management Systems ("DHR Table MR-2"). The minimums set forth in Table MT-2 may be increased further based on consideration of other factors (set forth in sections A—F) of the DHR Manual. (1) One hundred fifty percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-2 if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; (2) One hundred twenty-five percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-2 if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area; and (3) One hundred ten percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size calculated based on application of DHR Table MT-2 if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (h) Approval by health department required. No construction may proceed on a building or mobile home to be served by septic tanks unless the county health department first approves the proposed septic tank installations as meeting the requirements of the state department of human resources for on-site sewage management, and subsections (f) and (g) of this section. (Ord. No. 39, § 5, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-45. - Judicial review. (a) Jurisdiction. All final decisions of the county concerning denial, approval or conditional approval of a permit shall be reviewable in the county superior court. (b) Alternative actions. Based on these proceedings and the decision of the court, the county may, within the time specified by the court elect to: (1) Institute negotiated purchase or condemnation proceedings to acquire an easement of fee interest in the applicant's land; (2) Approve the permit application with lesser restrictions or conditions (i.e., grant a variance); or (3) Institute other appropriate actions ordered by the court that fall within the jurisdiction of the department of planning and zoning. (Ord. No. 39, § 6, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-46. - Amendments. This article may, from time to time, be amended in accordance with procedures and requirements in the general statutes and as new information becomes available. (Ord. No. 39, § 7, 4-12-2001) Sec. 46-47. - Assessment relief. Assessors and boards of assessors shall consider the requirements of these regulations in determining the fair market value of land. (Ord. No. 39, § 8, 4-12-2001)

div.head: Chapter 50 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Courts, ch. 26; law enforcement, ch. 38.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 50-1—50-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND MORALS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 50-31—50-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SMOKING IN COUNTY BUILDINGS AND FACILITIES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30.
Sec. 50-51. - Purpose. This division is enacted for and is designed for the following purposes, among others to: (1) Protect the public health and welfare of the general public by prohibiting smoking in all public buildings and facilities of the county; (2) Establish the priority that the general public is entitled to breathe air free of smoke; and (3) Prevent litter which normally results from smoking in public buildings and facilities. (Ord. No. 36, § 1, 4-2-1996) Sec. 50-52. - Definitions. The following, words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Public buildings and public facilities means and includes all those buildings and facilities owned and/or occupied by the county and its employees. Open land areas outside public buildings and public facilities are not included in this definition. Smoke or smoking means the act of burning a tobacco product of any kind in a cigarette, cigar or pipe. (Ord. No. 36, § 2, 4-2-1996) Sec. 50-53. - Signs. "No Smoking" signs shall be placed clearly and conspicuously at all entrances to public buildings and facilities and in such other places and areas as deemed necessary to give notice to the general public of the no smoking policy put into effect by this division. (Ord. No. 36, § 3, 4-2-1996) Sec. 50-54. - Enforcement. (a) Enforcement of the provisions of this division shall be by the county sheriff, his lawful deputies and any and all other law enforcement officers who have arrest powers under the general laws of this state, and also the code enforcement officer in the employment of the county. (b) Prosecutions for the violations of this division shall be by citation or accusation and made returnable to the court having jurisdiction of ordinance violations. (c) Jurisdiction for violations of this division shall be the magistrate court of the county. (d) Any person violating any provision of this division, and being found guilty thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or 60 days imprisonment, or both. (e) O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. shall govern in all matters under this division. (Ord. No. 36, § 4, 4-2-1996) Secs. 50-55—50-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC DRUNKENNESS
Sec. 50-81. - Definition; violation. (a) Any person who shall be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by boisterousness, by indecent condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud, or unbecoming language, is guilty of the offense of "public drunkenness." (b) Public drunkenness as defined in subsection (a) of this section shall constitute a violation of this division. (Ord. No. 49, §§ 1, 2, 6-12-2003) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 50-82. - Violation; penalty. (a) A violation of this division occurring in any part of the unincorporated area of the county shall be enforced by any law enforcement officer authorized by law to arrest for such conduct as permitted and provided by applicable sections of the Official Code of Georgia, Annotated. (b) Prosecution for violations of this division, trials for violations of this division, and punishment for violations of this division shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60—15-10-66. (c) A violation of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be tried in the magistrate's court of the county and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not in excess of 60 days, as provided by law. (Ord. No. 49, §§ 3—5, 6-12-2003) Secs. 50-83—50-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - DISORDERLY CONDUCT
Sec. 50-101. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Artifice means an artful device or strategy, or trickery. Assemble means to bring or gather into a group. Befoul means to soil or make dirty. Brawl means a noisy argument or fight. Congregate means to bring or come together in a crowd. Damage means impair or injure the usefulness or value of person or property. Device means a plan or scheme. Endanger means to expose to danger or harm. Epithets means a derogatory or abusive word or phrase used as a descriptive substitute for the name or title of a person or thing. Fighting words means words used in an argument or quarrel which are assertive or combative. Fraudulent scheme means a deliberate plan, deception, or trick practiced so as to secure an unfair or unlawful gain over someone. Gaming means gambling or betting money on the outcome of a game or contest, or to play a game of chance for stakes. Hazardous means dangerous. Lawful occupation means any regular employment which is allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by the law. Lawful pursuits means any activity regularly engaged in which is allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by the law. Obscene means offensive to the accepted standards of decency, or offensive, or repulsive to the senses. Physically offensive means disagreeble to the senses. Provoke means to cause someone or something to take action. Public property means any property which is maintained for or used by the people or community. Riotous conduct means unrestrained, disorderly, or uncontrolled behavior which causes a disturbance of the public peace. Trick means an indirect, often deceptive or fraudulent means of achieving an end. Tumultuous means confusedly or violently agitated so as to cause commotion, noise or a great disturbance. Turmoil means utter confusion or agitation. Unlawful activities means any activity engaged in which is not allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by the law. Utters means to express by means of speech. Violent means characterized or cause by great physical force or rough action. (Ord. No. 50, § 2, 6-12-2003) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 50-102. - Violation; prohibited acts of disorderly conduct. (a) Disorderly conduct as listed in subsection (b) of this section shall constitute a violation of this division. (b) Any person who shall do or engage in any of the following in the unincorporated area of the county shall be guilty of disorderly conduct: (1) Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby such person is placed in reasonable fear of the safety of such person's life, limb, or health. (2) Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person, whereby public property or the property of any other person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. (3) Endanger lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence or threats of bodily harm. (4) Cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another or public property. (5) Assemble or congregate with another or others and cause, provoke or engage in any fight or brawl. (6) Collect in bodies or in crowds and engage in unlawful activities. (7) Assemble or congregate with another or others and engage or attempt to engage in gaming. (8) Frequent any public place and obtain money from another by an illegal and fraudulent scheme, tricks, artifice or device, or attempt to do so. (9) Assembles with another or others and engages in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person, or attempts to do so. (10) Utters, in a public place or any place open to the public, any obscene words or epithets. (11) Frequents any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated. (12) Uses fighting words directed towards any person who becomes outraged, and thus creates turmoil. (13) Assemble or congregate with another or others and do bodily harm to another. (14) By acts of violence, interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation. (15) Congregate with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered to do so by a peace officer or other person having authority. (16) Damages, befouls or disturbs public property or the property of another so as to create a hazardous, unhealthy or physically offensive condition. (17) Assembles or congregates with others in a group or a crowd of more than five people in the parking lot or on the premises of a business establishment which is open and available to the public, not for the purpose of transacting business at the establishment, but for the purpose of socializing, hanging out, or consuming products purchased inside the business establishment, so as to interfere with or hinder the operation of the business activities conducted on the property or in the establishment served by such parking lot or premises by taking up parking spaces which are intended to be available for customers of the business, hampering access to the business establishment or by the existence of a group or crowd in the parking lot or on such premises discouraging potential customers from entering the premises of the business establishment; provided that the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment has complained about the situation to the sheriff's department and the sheriff or his deputy has advised the people in the group or crowd of the complaint of the business establishment, requested all those in the group or crowd to disperse and move out of the parking lot or on such premises and, after being given the opportunity to comply with the request, the person fails to remove himself from the parking lot or from such premises, or, in the alternative, the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment has posted and maintains, at points clearly visible from the place or places where the people are assembled or congregated, a sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing. a. Notice of this subsection (b)(17). b. Identification of the property reserved for customer use only. c. Identification of the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment. d. Warning that violators will be prosecuted. For purposes of determining whether a group or crowd of more than five people have assembled or congregated in a parking lot or on the premises, separate groups of less than five people engaging in the activity described above may be aggregated to determine the total number of people in the parking lot or on the premises participating in such activity. (18) Assembles or congregates with others in a group or a crowd of more than five people in the parking lot or on the premises of a business establishment which at the time is closed to the public, for the purpose of socializing, hanging out or other similar activities against the wishes of the owner, manager or operator of such business establishment; provided that the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment or their representative has complained about the situation to the sheriff's department and the sheriff or his deputy has advised the people in the group or crowd of the complaint of the business establishment, requested all those in the group or crowd to disperse and move out of the parking lot and, after being given the opportunity to comply with the request, the person fails to remove himself from the parking lot or, in the alternative, the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment or other representatives has posted and maintains, at points clearly visible from the place or places where the people are assembled or congregated, a sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing: a. Notice of this subsection (b)(18). b. Identification of the property reserved for customer use only. c. Identification of the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment. d. Warning that violators will be prosecuted. For purposes of determining whether a group or crowd of more than five people have assembled or congregated in a parking lot or on the premises, separate groups of less than five people engaging in the activity described above may be aggregated to determine the total number of people in the parking lot or on the premises participating in such activity. (19) Without provocation, uses obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of 14 years which threatens an immediate breach of the peace. (Ord. No. 50, §§ 1, 3, 6-12-2003) Sec. 50-103. - Violation; penalty. (a) A violation of this division occurring in any part of the unincorporated area of the county shall be enforced by any law enforcement officer authorized by law to arrest for such conduct as permitted and provided by applicable sections of the Official Code of Georgia, Annotated. (b) Prosecution for violations of this division, trials for violation of this division, and punishment for violations of this division shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60—15-10-66. (c) A violation of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be tried in the magistrate's court of the county and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not in excess of 60 days, as provided by law. (Ord. No. 50, §§ 4—6, 6-12-2003) Secs. 50-104—50-109. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - MARIJUANA
Sec. 50-110. - Definition; violation. (a) It should be unlawful for any person to possess, or have under his control marijuana, except for bona fide medical or scientific purposes, or for the bona fide purpose of applying marijuana for such medical or scientific purposes. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to common carriers or to warehousemen, while engaged in lawfully transacting their businesses as such, or to any employee of the same acting within the scope of his employment; or to public officers or their employees in the performance of their official duties requiring possession or control of marijuana; or to temporary incidental possession by employees or agents of persons lawfully entitled to possession, or by persons whose possession is for the purpose of aiding public officers in the performing their official duties. (c) The following words or phrases, as used in this section, shall have the following meanings, unless the context otherwise requires: (1) Marijuana includes the following substances, by whatever names they may be designated: a. The dried, flowering or fruiting tops of the pistillate plant Cannabis Sativa L., from which the resin has not been extracted. b. The resin extracted from such tops, and c. Every compound, manufacture, salt derivate, mixture of preparation of such resin, or such tops from which the resin has not been extracted. (2) Medical purposes include only such uses as may be prescribed or authorized in the course of his professional practice by a person authorized by law to practice medicine, dentistry, or veterinary medicine, or any other person authorized by law to treat sick or injured human beings or animals. (3) Person includes any corporation, association, co-partnership or one or more individuals. (4) Scientific purposes include any use for research, instruction or analysis. (Ord. of 2-11-2016) Sec. 50-111. - Penalty. A violation of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be tried in the probate court of the county and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed in excess of one year, as provided by law. (Ord. of 2-11-2016)

div.head: Chapter 54 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30; natural resources, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 62; waterways, ch. 74. State Constitution reference— County parks and recreational areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— County recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Other boards and commissions, § 2-141 et seq.
Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Recreation board means the Lincoln County Recreation Board. (Ord. No. 8, § 1, 2-4-1986) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-32. - Created. There is hereby created and established a recreation board for the county which shall be known as the "Lincoln County Recreation Board." (Ord. No. 8, § 1, 2-4-1986) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-33. - Membership. The recreation board created in this article shall consist of five members, one named by each of the five members of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 8, § 2, 2-4-1986) Sec. 54-34. - Eligibility; terms of office; vacancy and removal. (a) To be eligible for appointment to the recreation board, a member must be a resident of the county and reside within the boundaries of the district the member shall represent. (b) The members appointed under this article shall serve for four-year staggered terms beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31, four years later. (c) Vacancies in memberships of the recreation board shall be filled in the same manner as provided for the appointment of members. Any person appointed as the result of a vacancy on the board shall serve the unexpired term left by the vacant member. (d) Any members may be removed for cause by majority vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 8, § 3, 2-4-1986; Ord. of 2-8-2018) Sec. 54-35. - Oath of office. No member under this article shall begin to discharge his duties as a member of the recreation board without first having taken the oath of office. (Ord. No. 8, § 4, 2-4-1986) Sec. 54-36. - Organization. Immediately after appointment, the membership of the recreation board shall meet and organize by electing a chair, vice-chair and secretary. The recreation board may prepare and adopt bylaws, rules and regulations regarding the conduct of its affairs. (Ord. No. 8, § 5, 2-4-1986) Sec. 54-37. - Meetings. (a) The recreation board shall hold not less than eight regular meetings each calendar year. The meetings shall be held on the fourth Tuesday of the months of March through October. (b) Reserved. (c) Nothing in this section shall prohibit the recreation board holding special meetings on the call of the chair of the recreation board; however no travel allotment shall be paid to a member except for those meetings attended as provided for in subsection (a) of this section. (d) The membership of any member of the recreation board missing more than three meetings of the board during any calendar year shall be automatically terminated under this section. (Ord. No. 8, § 6, 2-4-1986; Amend. of 2-12-2009) Sec. 54-38. - Reports. The recreation board shall submit a written report to the board of commissioners of its transactions, findings, proceedings and recommendations at least once per year. (Ord. No. 8, § 7, 2-4-1986) Sec. 54-39. - Duties. The recreation board has as its primary responsibility the coordination, organization and scheduling of recreational and cultural programs to meet the needs and desires of the citizens of the county. The board shall advise and recommend to the board of commissioners, as to the assessment and collection of fees for use of county recreational facilities and participation in organizing recreational activities. (Ord. No. 8, § 8, 2-4-1986) Secs. 54-40—54-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARK AND RECREATION FACILITIES
Sec. 54-71. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcoholic beverage means any wine or malt beverage as defined under the terms of article II of chapter 10 as amended, and distilled spirits and other liquors as defined under O.C.G.A. title 3, and any and all other such substances that may be considered to be alcoholic beverages under state and county law. Possession means the control or having of alcoholic beverages on or about the person or premises of an individual, including having the beverage on or about the premises of a motor vehicle, possession shall be deemed to be by the person having responsibility for and/or control of the motor vehicle. Recreation complex means all that tract or parcel of land lying and being in the 186th District C.M., Lincoln County, Georgia Recreation Department Complex. The recreation complex includes all and any existing buildings, recreational structures, playing courts and fields now, or which shall become located thereon and become a part thereof. (Ord. No. 3, § 1, 3-10-1983) Sec. 54-72. - Hours of operation. All public parks located in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be opened from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. each day, unless otherwise posted at the entrance to such parks; provided, however, the hours when the public parks are closed shall not apply to persons using the parks for purposes of launching or removing boats, fishing or camping in areas designated for camping within such parks. (Ord. No. 7, § 1, 6-4-1985) Sec. 54-73. - Alcoholic beverages. (a) No person shall use, possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in public within any public park located in the unincorporated area of the county. (b) It shall be unlawful to possess, distribute, consume and/or otherwise use and/or control alcoholic beverages upon the property of the recreation complex. (Ord. No. 3, § 2, 3-10-1983; Ord. No. 7, § 1 6-4-1985) Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10. Sec. 54-74. - Enforcement, prosecution and punishment. (a) Enforcement of this article shall be by the county sheriff, his lawful deputies, and any and other law enforcement agents who may be charged by state laws with the responsibility of enforcement of local ordinances, and including officers of any municipal police agency whose jurisdiction may include a portion or all of the recreation complex property, and members of the state patrol. (b) Violations of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. (Ord. No. 3, § 3, 3-10-1983; Ord. No. 7, § 1, 6-4-1985) Sec. 54-75. - Parking fees. (a) The county board of commissioners may determine that a fee must be paid to park at a public park for a specific length of time. The amount of the fee as well as the time limits will be posted on signage at the public park. (b) In any public parks where a fee for parking is charged, it shall be unlawful to enter without depositing the required amount at the designated deposit box. (c) Enforcement shall be through a civil action in the magistrate court by the issuance of a citation, which shall either be left with the vehicle or delivered to the person in possession thereof by the county sheriff or any other law enforcement officer as provided in section 54-74. (1) For purposes of such civil action, it shall be presumed that the owner of said vehicle is in control and possession thereof. In the event any person is found to have violated this paragraph, such person shall be subject to a fine of $25.00, if paid within five days and $40.00 if paid after five days; provided, however, that if a person is found to have violated this paragraph twice within 180 days of the first offense, such person shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 if paid within five days, and $75.00 if paid after five days; and the third or later citations, if received within 180 days of the first offense, such person shall be subject to $100.00 if paid within five days and $150.00 if paid after five days. For any new tickets received after the 180-day period, the parking fines set forth herein shall revert to the "First Citation" status after the expiration of 180 days from the first offense set forth herein for any other tickets written. (2) All fines imposed as punishment for violation shall be paid within ten calendar days to the magistrate court clerk. For purposes of this section, the ten-calendar-day period shall exclude the day of the event, count all days including Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, and include the last day of the period, unless the last day is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. In the event that the last day is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the period continues to run until the end of the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. Failure to pay such fines within this time period shall subject the person to contempt proceedings. (d) With regard to all parking areas for which a time limitation is established, it shall be deemed a separate violation thereof for each successive time period in which any vehicle is parked therein in excess of such limitation. (e) The vehicle of any person which accumulates an excess of ten citations under this chapter and fails to satisfy the fines accompanying the citations shall be impounded by any officer listed in subparagraph (c). The vehicle shall be held until accumulated fines and wrecker fees have been paid in full. (Ord. of 6-10-2010)

div.head: Chapter 56 - PUBLIC SAFETY
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 56-1. - Authority. This chapter is enacted pursuant to the authority granted by Georgia Constitution of 1983, Article 9, Section 2, Paragraph 2 and 3; and O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20, as amended. (Ord. of 5-8-2008) Sec. 56-2. - Short title. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Public Safety Ordinance of Lincoln County, Georgia." (Ord. of 5-8-2008) Sec. 56-3. - Purposes. The public health, safety, and general welfare require that the citizens and property of Lincoln County be protected, whenever jeopardized during an emergency, disaster, whether natural or manmade, and during the subsequent recovery periods. In furtherance of this general intent, the public safety ordinance is adopted to provide for the health and safety of persons and property, provided that such actions are not inconsistent with any orders, rules or regulations promulgated by the Governor or his delegatee and General Assembly of Georgia. (Ord. of 5-8-2008) Sec. 56-4. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Terms not defined in this section shall have the meaning customarily assigned to them.
